docket_entries.description: MINUTES OF Status Conference held before Judge Dolly M. Gee: The hearing is held via videoconference. The Court and counsel confer regarding the status of the action. A joint status report is due by 6/30/2021. Court Reporter: Miranda Algorri. (gk) (Entered: 06/01/2021)

PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION by Judge Dolly M. Gee: The Court has found that entry of a preliminary injunction is warranted. Based on the law and facts presented in the Cross-Motions for Partial Summary Judgment (Doc. Nos. 263, 271), Plaintiffs have demonstrated that they are likely to succeed on the merits of parts of their claims and are likely to suffer irreparable injury in the absence of a preliminary injunction. The Court ORDERS that the Office of Refugee Resettlement ("ORR") its agents, employees, attorneys, and all those who are in active concert or participation with them, are preliminarily enjoined as described in this order. This injunction goes into effect 60 days from the date of entry of this Order. Consistent with the Court's 3/11/2022 Order, this Preliminary Injunction will remain in effect until final judgment is entered. See document for further details. (gk) (Entered: 08/30/2022)

MINUTE IN CHAMBERS - TRANSFER OF CASE TO JUDGE GEE. Please take notice that this action has been reassigned to the HONORABLE DOLLY M. GEE, United States District Judge, pursuant to the Order re Transfer Pursuant to General Order 16-05 filed on July 5, 2018. Please substitute the initials DMG in place of the current initials, so that the case number will now read CV 18-5741-DMG (PLAx). As documents are routed using the judge's initials, it is imperative that the correct initials DMG be used on all subsequent filings to prevent any delays in the processing of documents. Judge Gee's Courtroom Deputy Clerk is Kane Tien. He can be reached at (213) 894-5452. Judge Gee's courtroom is located on the 8th floor of the First Street Courthouse, Courtroom #8C. Additional information about Judge Gee's procedures and schedules is available on the court's website at www.cacd.uscourt.gov. (shb) (Entered: 07/06/2018)

MINUTES (IN CHAMBERS) ORDER RE PLAINTIFF LUCAS R.'S EX PARTE APPLICATION 64 by Judge Dolly M. Gee: Good cause appearing, the Court GRANTS Lucas R.'s Ex Parte Application that the Court decide the motion without a hearing. In addition, however, the Court orders Defendants to file, by September 4, 2018, a declaration from an official from the Office of Refugee Resettlement ("ORR") providing the identities and locations of: (1) the ORR Federal Field Specialist with responsibility for supervising the operations of Shiloh Residential Treatment Center (i.e., the location of Lucas R.'s confinement), and (2) the ORR Federal Field Specialist with responsibility for supervising the operations of St. Michael's Home for Children shelter facility (i.e., the location of Gabriela N.'s confinement). Lucas R.'s motion for preliminary injunction shall be taken under submission upon Defendants' filing of that declaration. The remainder of the Court's August 23, 2018 Order remains in full force and effect 61 .IT IS SO ORDERED. (See order for details.) (kti) (Entered: 08/28/2018)

ORDER RE APPLICATION TO FILE CERTAIN EXHIBITS IN SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFF'S MOTION FOR PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION UNDER SEAL by Judge Dolly M. Gee: Upon Plaintiff's Unopposed Application 30, it is hereby ORDERED that: (1) Plaintiff is granted leave to file in the public record redacted versions of Exhibits 3337, 4142, and 44 in support of his motion for preliminary injunction, which are found at Docket Entry No. 33. Plaintiff shall refile the redacted versions of these documents within three days of the date of this Order. (2) Plaintiff is granted leave to file under seal the unredacted versions of Exhibits 33-37, 4142, and 44 and the entirety of Exhibits 38 and 40, all of which are found at Docket Entry No. 32-1. Pursuant to Local Rule 79-5.2.2(c), Plaintiff shall efile these documents under seal within three days of the date of this Order. (3) Docket Entry No. 29-2 shall remain sealed. In Plaintiff's motion for preliminary injunction, he refers to Exhibit 43 [Doc. No. 29-1 at 16], which is found at Docket Entry No. 29-2. Yet, Exhibit 43 is missing from Docket Entry Nos. 32-1 and 33. Therefore, within three days of the date of this Order, Plaintiff shall either file an application to file Exhibit 43 under seal, or file a publicly viewable version of that document. (gk) (Entered: 08/08/2018)

ORDER GRANTING MOTION TO MODIFY THE COURT'S CLASS CERTIFICATION ORDER by Judge Dolly M. Gee: Having reviewed Plaintiffs' Motion to Modify the Court's Order Granting Class Certification and for the Limited Purpose of Substituting Class Counsel 414, the Court finds that appointment of Brenda Shum and Mishan Wroe as Class Counsel is appropriate. Plaintiffs' Motion is hereby GRANTED. The Court's prior Amended Order re Defendants' Motion to Dismiss and Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification, [Doc. No. 141], is AMENDED as follows: (1) Jon Cieslak, Mary Kathryn Kelley, and Megan Donohue are removed as Class Counsel. (2) Leecia Welch and Neha Desai, formerly of NCYL, are removed as Class Counsel. (3) Brenda Shum and Mishan Wroe ofNCYL are appointed as Class Counsel. (4) Poonam Juneja of NCYL, Carlos Holguin of the Center for Human Rights & Constitutional Law, Holly S. Cooper and Carter C. White of the University of California Davis School of Law, and Summer Wynn of Cooley LLP shall continue as Class Counsel. (gk) (Entered: 05/03/2024)

ORDER RE DEFENDANTS MOTION TO DISMISS, PLAINTIFFS MOTION FOR DECLARATORY JUDGMENT, AND PARTIES CROSS-MOTIONS FOR FINAL JUDGMENT [440, 441] by Judge Dolly M. Gee: In light of the foregoing, Defendants Motion to Dismiss Plaintiffs first and second claims for relief is DENIED, Plaintiffs Motion for Declaratory Judgment regarding their first and second claims for relief is GRANTED, and the Court will enter final judgment in this action consistent wit h the following: 1. In entering final judgment, the Court hereby INCORPORATES its findings and legal conclusions in the MSJ Order entered March 11, 2022, with respect to Plaintiffs first claim for relief on behalf of the unfit custodian class and second claim for relief on behalf of the step-up class. See MSJ Order [Doc. # 376]. 2. Regarding Plaintiffs psychotropic medications, legal representation, and disability claims, as provided in the Parties Agreements and approved by the Court on May 3, 2024, the Court will retain jurisdiction over its judgment and [Approval Order] only for the purposes of interpreting and enforcing the Agreements until the Termination Dates, as set forth in the Agreements. See Approval Order at 3 [Doc. # 433]. IT IS SO ORDERED. (shb) (Entered: 09/17/2024)

JUDGMENT by Judge Dolly M. Gee. IT IS ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED that  judgment is entered in favor   of Plaintiffs and against Defendants on  Plaintiffs' first and second claims,  and that this  action is dismissed on the merits, in accorda nce with the following: 1. In   entering final judgment, the Court hereby INCORPORATES its findings and legal   conclusions in the MSJ Order entered March 11, 2022, with respect to    Plaintiffs'   first claim for relief on behalf of the "u nfit custodian class" and second   claim for   relief on behalf of the "step-up class." See MSJ Order [Doc. # 376].  2. Regarding Plaintiffs' "psychotropic medications," "legal representation,"   and  "dis ability" claims, as provided in the Parties' Agreements and approved by  the   Court on May 3, 2024, "the Court will retain jurisdiction over its  judgment and    [Approval Order] only for the purposes of interpreting and enforcing the    Agreements   until the Termination Dates, as set forth in the Agreements." See  Approval  Order at 3 [Doc. # 433].    (MD JS-6, Case Terminated).      (lom)

ORDER RE DEFENDANTS' EX PARTE APPLICATION TO EXTEND BRIEFING SCHEDULE AND CONTINUE HEARING DATE by Judge Dolly M. Gee: The Court has read and considered Defendants' Ex Parte Application for an extension of the briefing schedule and a continuance of the hearing on Plaintiffs' Motion for Attorneys' Fees and Costs under the Equal Access to Justice Act ("EPA") 458 . Finding no good cause for the requested relief, the Court DENIES in part Defendants' EPA. Despite the foregoing, however, Plaintiffs have indicated that they are amenable to a 30-day extension of the deadlines and continuance of the hearing. Thus, in the interests of justice, the Court hereby EXTENDS the briefing schedule and CONTINUES the hearing on Plaintiffs' motion for an order awarding them attorneys' fees and other expenses under the Equal Access to Justice Act 455 to 6/6/2025 at 9:30 AM before Judge Dolly M. Gee. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Defendants shall file their response to Plaintiffs' Motion by 3/21/2025. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Plaintiffs shall file their reply in support of Plaintiffs' Motion by 5/23/2025. (gk) (Entered: 02/20/2025)

MINUTES OF Motion Hearing held before Judge Dolly M. Gee RE: Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification 97 ; Defendants' Motion to Dismiss, and Alternative Motion to Transfer 101 . The Court invites counsel to respond to the tentative ruling. Parties submit on the tentative ruling. The tentative ruling stands and a written order will issue. Defendants request for an extension of time to file an answer to the first amended complaint is GRANTED. Defendants shall file their answer by 1/4/2019. Court Reporter: Anne Kielwasser. (gk) (Entered: 11/05/2018)

MINUTES OF IN CHAMBERS - ORDER RE DEFENDANTS MOTION TO DISMISS AND PLAINTIFFS' MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION by Judge Dolly M. Gee: The Court GRANTS IN PART and DENIES IN PART Defendants' Motion to Dismiss or Transfer ("MTD") 101 and GRANTS Plaintiffs' Motion for Class Certification 97 . Defendants' MTD is GRANTED only insofar as it seeks the dismissal without prejudice of Plaintiffs' claims to enforce the Flores Agreement, but not insofar as it requests the dismissal of Plaintiffs' claims that ORR failed to provide sufficient procedural safeguards for alien minors to exercise their Flores rights. The remainder of Defendants' MTD is DENIED. Defendants shall file an Answer to the First Amended Complaint within 60 days of the date of this Order. The Court CERTIFIES five classes that are comprised of all minors in Office of Refugee Resettlement custody pursuant to 6 U.S.C. section 279 and/or 8 U.S.C. section 1232. See document for classes, appointed class representatives, and appointed class counsel. Court Reporter: Not Reported. (gk) (Entered: 11/05/2018)

MINUTES OF IN CHAMBERS - ORDER RE CLASS MEMBERS' EX PARTE APPLICATION FOR TEMPORARY RESTRAINING ORDER AND ORDER TO SHOW CAUSE RE PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION by Judge Dolly M. Gee: On 3/25/2020, in light of the Coronavirus Disease 2019 ("COVID-19") public health crisis, Plaintiffs filed an Ex Parte Application for a Temporary Restraining Order ("TRO") and an Order to Show Cause ("OSC") why a preliminary injunction should not issue, arguing that the members of the unfit custodian class should be immediately released unless Defendants can justify keeping them in ORR facilities 227 . The Court held a hearing on the TRO application in conjunction with the hearing on a TRO application filed in the related case of Flores v. Barr, No. 85-4544-DMG (AGRx) (C.D. Cal.). On 3/28/2020, the Court granted in part the Flores Plaintiffs' ex parte application for a TRO ("the Flores TRO"). Having duly considered the parties written submissions and oral argument in light of the applicable legal standard for mandatory injunctive relief, and having issued the TRO in Flores that renders the most urgent portions of Plaintiffs' request for interim relief moot, the Court DENIES the Ex Parte Application and OSC re preliminary injunction. Court Reporter: Not Reported. (gk) (Entered: 04/02/2020)

MINUTES OF Motion Hearing held before Judge Dolly M. Gee RE: Defendants' Motion for Summary Judgment Pursuant to FRCP 56 263 ; Plaintiffs' Motion for Partial Summary Judgment 271 . The Court invites counsel to respond to the oral tentative ruling. Following oral argument, the Court advises counsel that the motions shall be taken under submission and a written order will issue. The parties shall meet and confer and submit a joint status report by 2/1/2021. The Court VACATES the amended schedule of pretrial and trial (Doc. No. 253). New dates and deadlines shall be reset after the parties meet and confer and submit their joint status report re new dates. Court Reporter: Miriam Baird. (gk) (Entered: 12/23/2020)

MINUTES OF IN CHAMBERS - ORDER RE SUPPLEMENTAL SUBMISSIONS, PRETRIAL DATES AND DEADLINES, AND JOINT STATUS REPORT by Judge Dolly M. Gee: On 12/22/2020, the Court held a hearing on the parties' cross-Motions for Summary Judgment and issued its tentative oral ruling regarding Plaintiffs' step-up class, unfit custodian class, and legal representation class claims 263, 271 . In light of the matters discussed at the hearing, the Court hereby ORDERS: (1) By 1/5/2021, the parties shall file a joint supplemental submission with the current version of the form Notice of Placement ("NOP") given to minors stepped-up to more restrictive placements, to be filed publicly. (2) By 1/5/2021, Plaintiffs shall file a supplemental submission describing any incidents where a stepped-up minor was incorrectly found to be a danger to self or others that occurred after the Court's Order in Flores v. Sessions, No. CV 85-4544-DMG (AGRx), 2018 WL 10162328 (C.D. Cal. July 30, 2018). (3) Because the parties have another mediation scheduled for 1/11/2021, and the parties' current pretrial and trial dates and deadlines are infeasible, all scheduled dates are VACATED. (4) The parties shall meet and confer regarding their claims in light of the Court's tentative oral ruling and submit a Joint Status Report on the status of those meetings by 2/1/2021. (5) A written order on the pending motions shall issue, if necessary, after the Joint Status Report is filed. Court Reporter: Not Reported. (gk) (Entered: 12/23/2020)

case_data.name: L.R. (Lucas R.) v. Azar
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
special_collections: Trump Administration 1.0: Challenges to the Government
case_data.summary:
This class action suit, filed on June 29, 2018, sought to enjoin the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), of which ORR is a component part, from causing grave harm to migrant and asylum-seeking children in its care. 2018 WL 3209193. The plaintiffs--represented by the Center for Human Rights & Constitutional Law, National Center for Youth Law, the Immigration Law Clinic at the UC Davis Law School, and private counsel--were members of the class protected under the consent decree issued in Flores v. Reno (“Flores Settlement”), available here in the Clearinghouse. The plaintiffs alleged violations of that Settlement, the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) 8 U.S.C. § 1101, William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Reauthorization Act of 2008 (TVPRA) 18 U.S.C. § 1589, the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) 5 U.S.C. § 703, as well as the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause and First Amendment’s Freedom of Association Clause. They sued the Secretary of HHS and the Director of ORR under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331, 2241, the APA, Bivens, the TVPRA, and the rights conferred to the plaintiffs in the Flores Settlement. They sought injunctive and declaratory relief, a writ of habeas corpus for their release from ORR custody, nominal damages, and attorneys’ fees. The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California and assigned to Judge Dolly Maizie Gee.

The named plaintiffs were several children in ORR custody (in facilities in Texas, California, New York, and Michigan) and two nonprofit organizations, the San Fernando Valley Refugee Children Center, Inc. and the Unaccompanied Central American Refugee Empowerment. The plaintiffs alleged that ORR confined unaccompanied children in residential treatment centers (RTCs) without a meaningful opportunity to challenge allegations that they were dangerous or posed a flight risk or that their parents or other custodians were unfit to care for them. The complaint also stated that the children were detained in conditions where they were administered psychotropic medication for weeks, months, or longer without parental consent or any other procedural safeguards. Several children were reportedly prescribed medications that increased suicidality, intentional self harm, pain, nausea, insomnia, and other symptoms in children. One of the children alleged they were assaulted by staff on multiple occasions, including with pepper spray, but that no disciplinary action was taken.

The four proposed classes included all children in ORR custody (a) whom ORR refused to release to their parents or other available custodians who completed family reunification packets but were allegedly unfit, (b) who had been or would be in an RTC or other facility for more than 30 days without notice and an opportunity to be heard regarding release, (c) who had been or would be administered psychotropic medication without procedural safeguards (e.g., parental consent), and (d) who were natives of non-contiguous countries and to whom ORR blocks legal assistance in matters related to their custody, medication, and release.

On July 9, 2018, Judge Gee granted the plaintiffs leave to use pseudonyms for the named plaintiffs and their next friends (i.e., family members, custodians, or sponsors), who sued on their behalf, and ordered the parties to use these pseudonyms in all documents filed with the court. The court subsequently granted leave to both parties to file documents under seal in order to protect the identities of the minors.

On August 2, 2018, the plaintiffs moved to certify the classes. On August 3, 2018, one named plaintiff detained in a southern Texas facility, moved for a preliminary injunction for his release from ORR custody “without unnecessary delay” as provided by the Flores Settlement and the TVPRA. On August 17, 2018, another named plaintiff detained in a southern Texas facility similarly moved for a preliminary injunction for her release.

On August 17, 2018, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss for improper venue and for failure to state a claim for which the court can grant relief. The defendants argued that this lawsuit was duplicative of the Flores litigation, and claimed that the plaintiffs were trying to rewrite or re-bargain that settlement by bringing this case.

On September 6 and 10, 2018, the court denied both preliminary injunction motions for lack of jurisdiction. 2018 WL 10483438. In both cases, the court found that the cited sections of the Flores Settlement and the APA did not authorize the court to order the release of the minors. The motions were dismissed without prejudice, indicating that they could refile in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas against the ORR Field Specialists in Texas responsible for the minors’ care. Judge Gee found that habeas matters would be properly venued before those specialists in that court if the plaintiffs were to refile.

On September 7, 2018, the plaintiffs filed their first amended complaint, which included two more named plaintiffs and additional detail concerning the original complaint's named plaintiffs’ mental health, including hospitalization due to their extreme distress at not being released to their families. 2018 WL 8803996. It also described fundraising and other community efforts made in preparation of the children’s release.

On September 10, 2018, Judge Gee denied the defendants’ motion to dismiss as moot because the plaintiff’s amended complaint was treated as superseding the first. In the same order, she denied the plaintiff’s motion for class certification without prejudice, reasoning that it would be more efficient to decide on that motion at a later date, because it was anticipated that the defendants would again move to have the case dismissed.

On September 18, 2018, the defendants did again move to have the complaint dismissed for improper venue and failure to state a claim. On September 28, 2018, the defendants supplemented their motion to dismiss, requesting that the case be transferred to the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia if it were not dismissed.

Also on September 28, 2018, the plaintiffs again moved to certify the classes. These first four class definitions were the same as those in their August motion for class certification; the new motion added one more class, including only children who had or would have a behavioral, mental health, or intellectual and/or developmental disability and who were placed in an ORR facility because of that disability.

On November 2, 2018, Judge Gee issued an order granting in part and denying in part the defendants' motion to dismiss and granting the plaintiffs' motion for class certification. 2018 WL 10111336. The defendants' motion to dismiss was granted only with regard to the plaintiffs' claims to enforce the Flores Agreement, but was denied in all other respects, including the plaintiffs' claims that "ORR failed to provide sufficient procedural safeguards for alien minors to exercise their Flores rights." In the order granting the plaintiffs' motion for class certification, Judge Gee certified each of the proposed classes but slightly re-wrote the definitions of some classes.

On November 16, 2018, the defendants filed a motion for reconsideration of the court's November 2 order, asserting that in re-writing the definitions of certain classes, the court failed to consider material facts and denied defendants the opportunity to address the newly created class. On December 27, 2018, Judge Gee issued an order granting in part and denying in part the defendants' motion for reconsideration and simultaneously issued an amended version of the November 2 order. 2018 WL 7200716 and 2018 WL 10483527. The amended order made a slight change to the "disability class" (described below) to reflect the defendants' concern with the class definition. 

The court approved 5 classes, encompassing: “all minors in ORR custody pursuant to 6 U.S.C. section 279 and/or 8 U.S.C. section 1232: 

a. who are or will be placed in a secure facility, medium-secure facility, or RTC, or whom ORR has continued to detain in any such facility for more than 30 days, without being afforded notice and an opportunity to be heard before a neutral and detached decisionmaker regarding the grounds for such placement (i.e., the “step-up class”);

b. whom ORR is refusing or will refuse to release to parents or other available custodians within 30 days of the proposed custodian’s submission of a complete family reunification packet on the ground that the proposed custodian is or may be unfit (i.e., the “unfit custodian class”); 

c. who are or will be prescribed or administered one or more psychotropic medications without procedural safeguards;

d. who are natives of non-contiguous countries and to whom ORR is impeding or will impede legal assistance in legal matters or proceedings involving their custody, placement, release, and/or administration of psychotropic drugs (i.e., the “legal representation class”); and

e. who have or will have a behavioral, mental health, intellectual, and/or developmental disability as defined in 29 U.S.C. section 705, and who are or will be placed in a secure facility, medium-secure facility, or RTC solely by reason of such disabilities (i.e., the “disability class”).”

On March 2, 2019, defendant E. Scott Lloyd -- the former Director of ORR who was also sued in his individual capacity under Bivens -- filed a motion to dismiss the plaintiffs' complaint and action against him for lack of personal jurisdiction and a motion for judgment on the pleadings. The defendant asserted that the complaint did not establish that the court had personal jurisdiction over him, failed to give notice of the claims against him, failed to state a claim upon which relief can be granted against him, and failed to defeat his qualified immunity.

On April 23, 2019, following the parties' stipulation for mediation, Judge Gee issued an order referring the matter to Magistrate Judge Sheri Pym for mediation proceedings. Over the next several months, the parties underwent the discovery process and conferred to attempt to reach a settlement.

On August 21, 2019, Judge Gee issued an order granting Lloyd's motion for judgment on the pleadings, concluding that the plaintiffs' Bivens claim against him was not "supported by a cognizable legal theory" and because "special factors counsel against recognizing such a remedy in this context." 2019 WL 6655262. As such, the individual defendant in his individual capacity was dismissed.

On March 25, 2020, in light of the nationwide outbreak of COVID-19, the plaintiffs filed an ex parte application for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and for issuance of an order to show cause why a preliminary injunction should not be issued. The plaintiffs requested that the court issue an order "requiring ORR to release children it has already detained for 30 days to ready custodians, transfer them to non-congregate settings, or else justify why it has done neither." At the time the application was filed, there were a reported 46,481 cases in the U.S. and 593 deaths and several staff members at ORR facilities had tested positive for COVID-19. No cure or vaccine existed at the time of filing so social distancing and frequent hand washing were the only effective measures to prevent the transmission of COVID-19. The plaintiffs contended that the "vast majority of children in ORR custody live in congregate settings, where they spend all of their time in close proximity to other children and staff members" and are thus unable to practice effective methods of preventing transmission. Moreover, while the elderly and those with underlying health conditions remained the most vulnerable to serious illness or death from COVID-19, the plaintiffs stated that "approximately 6% of infected children and 11% of infected infants had severe or critical cases," demonstrating a risk of severe harm to the plaintiffs. The plaintiffs urged that a TRO was appropriate because “[t]he Flores Settlement, the TVPRA, and the First and Fifth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution each vest children who have custodians available to receive them with substantive rights against ORR’s keeping them in congregate care, especially during a global pandemic."

On March 27, 2020, the government filed an opposition to the plaintiffs' motion for TRO. The government asserted that if there was a claim that the Flores Settlement Agreement has been violated, that claim "must proceed in a Flores enforcement action." The government also argued that the plaintiffs' due process claim lacked merit, proclaiming that they had "gone to extraordinary lengths to care for children in a profoundly challenging situation, while also fulfilling its statutory mandate under the TVPRA for expeditious release of children to custodians who will care for them, implementing measures both to prevent the spread of COVID-19 and provide appropriate medical care in the case of infection." Finally, the government contended that, considering the risk posed by the proposed mass transit of plaintiffs and strained resources for administrative hearings caused by COVID-19, plaintiffs "fail to show how their alleged injury would be redressed by the relief they seek."

On March 28, 2020, Judge Gee issued a TRO in Flores v. Reno, ordering the government to promptly adjudicate the class members' claims for release to outside sponsors and for the inspection of government facilities to ensure compliance with public health guidelines.

Following oral argument on April 2, 2020, Judge Gee issued an order denying the plaintiffs' application for TRO and an order to show cause. Judge Gee concluded that the TRO issued in Flores rendered "the most urgent portions of Plaintiffs’ request for interim relief moot," and thus a TRO here was not appropriate.

On October 2, 2020, the defendants moved for partial summary judgment. They alleged that some of the claims were barred by res judicata, as the Court had already decided the issues in Flores v. Reno. The defendants further argued that, even if the claims were not barred, the policies and procedures implemented satisfied the judicial standards for procedural due process. The same day, the plaintiffs also moved for partial summary judgment on different claims. The plaintiffs argued that the defendants' non-compliance with the Flores Settlement Agreement violated their right to procedural due process, and required court intervention. The court held a hearing on this cross-motion for summary judgment on December 22, 2020.

On March 11, 2022, Judge Gee issued an order granting in part and denying in part plaintiffs' Motion for Partial Summary Judgment, as well as granting in part and denying in part defendants' Motion for Partial Summary Judgment. 2022 WL 2177454. Judge Gee ordered:

  • Regarding the “step-up class”: Granted relief as to plaintiffs’ due process claim in part, requiring several specific actions of defendants, including providing specific criteria for and employing a “clear and convincing” evidentiary standard deciding when minors may be transferred. Issued judgment in defendants’ favor on the TVPRA/APA claim.
  • Regarding the “unfit custodian class”: Granted relief as to plaintiffs’ due process claim in part, requiring several specific actions of defendants, including ensuring written notice to denied sponsors and instating an automatic review of pending family reunification applications every 90 days. Issued judgment in defendants’ favor on the TVPRA/APA claim. Issued judgment against defendants’ First Amendment claim without prejudice.
  • Regarding the “legal representation class”: Issued “summary judgment to Defendants on Plaintiffs’ due process and TVPRA/APA claim that ORR must fund their legal representation in challenging ORR’s administrative decisions.” Granted relief as to plaintiffs’ due process claim in part, requiring several specific actions of defendants, including providing minors assistance of counsel and providing case files to legal representatives when requested. Issued judgment against “the parties’ cross-summary judgment motions as to the remainder of the legal representation class’ claims that relate to access to counsel to challenge decisions regarding psychotropic drugs and whether ORR blocks counsel from representing minors in challenging ORR decisions.” 

Judge Gee also ordered that the parties confer and submit a proposed preliminary injunction by April 1, 2022. The parties conferred several times but were unable to reach an agreed-upon proposed injunction, and on August 30, 2022, Judge Gee issued a preliminary injunction:

  • Regarding the “step-up class”: the injunction required that ORR issue a Notice Of Placement (NOP) within 48 hours after step-up to a restrictive placement, as well as every 30 days the minor remained in a restrictive placement, along with procedures for minors to contest placement before a Placement Review Panel and administrative review processes.  
  • Regarding the “unfit custodian class”: the injunction established automatic reviews every 90 days for pending Family Reunification Applications, as well as procedures for providing written notice of denials and for appealing ORR decisions.
  • Regarding the “legal representation class”: the injunction required that ORR serve a minor’s NOP on counsel, permit minors assistance of counsel, and provide case files to a minor’s counsel upon request.

2022 WL 3908829. The preliminary injunction was slightly modified on September 27, 2022, editing the language of the procedure for the "unfit custodian class."

On November 14, 2023, the parties submitted a joint motion for settlement approval. After a fairness hearing, Judge Gee issued orders on May 3, 2024, granting a motion to modify the class certification by changing the lawyers representing the classes, granting a joint motion to appoint a monitor, and granting final approval of settlements for the plaintiffs’ 3rd, 4th, and 5th, claims, also noting that the parties “shall meet and confer in good faith to attempt to settle attorneys' fees and costs.” The settlement required ORR to implement policies and procedural protections regarding the administration of psychotropic medications, access to legal representation, and the placement and release of children with disabilities. Kathleen Noonan was selected to monitor the implementation of and compliance with these policies and procedures, and defendants agreed to submit compliance reports to Noonan every 6 months. 

The agreement regarding psychotropic medications was to terminate six years after the effective date, or earlier if the defendants moved for early termination and were able to show continued compliance after three years from the effective date. The agreement regarding legal representation was to terminate three years after the effective date, unless Congressional action were to supersede the agreement prior to the termination date. The agreement regarding the placement and release of children with disabilities was to terminate five years after the effective date, or earlier if the defendants moved for early termination and were able to show continued compliance after two years from the implementation date.

On March 12, 2024, because Magistrate Judge Pym was no longer available, the case was reassigned to Magistrate Judge Brianna Fuller Mircheff.

On May 14, 2024, the parties issued a joint notice, stating that they had met regarding the defendants’ anticipated motion to dissolve the preliminary injunction. The parties agreed that once the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Administration for Children and Families’ Foundational Rule (89 Fed. Reg. 34384, 34585 (Apr. 30, 2024)) went into effect, the preliminary injunction should be dissolved. At the time of the statement, the anticipated effective date of the Foundational Rule was July 1, 2024, and the parties planned to inform the court of the status of the implementation around July 1. On July 2, 2024, the parties filed a joint stipulation to dissolve the preliminary injunction, which Judge Gee then ordered dissolved on the same day. 

On July 12, 2024, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss for mootness, and on July 26, 2024, the plaintiffs filed a motion for declaratory judgment on their due process claims (regarding determining custodial fitness and restrictive placement). 

Following briefings on the matter, Judge Gee issued an order on the motion to dismiss and motion for declaratory judgment on September 16, 2024. First, the defendants’ motion to dismiss was denied. Although commending the promulgation of the Foundational Rule, the court determined that because ORR was not a legislative body, the rule’s “permanence” was not guaranteed. Considering 46 senators had then introduced a joint resolution pursuant to the Congressional Review Act (“CRA”) to undo the Foundational Rule, the court determined that it was not “absolutely clear” that there was no reasonable expectation of recurrence of injuries to the plaintiffs. As such, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion for declaratory judgment given the need to “afford relief from the uncertainty, insecurity, and controversy giving rise to the proceeding”—the plaintiffs would find themselves and their rights back at square one in the absence of the Rule or the Court’s now-dissolved preliminary injunction. Final judgment was subsequently entered in favor of the plaintiffs and the action was dismissed on the merits. 2024 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 167645. 

Following the entry of a final judgment in their favor, the plaintiffs filed a motion to recuperate attorney’s fees and other expenses under the Equal Access to Justice Act (EAJA) on December 13, 2024. A hearing on the matter was initially scheduled for May 9, 2025; however, this was opposed by the defendants who sought to continue the hearing until July 11, 2025. As of February 2025, the case remains ongoing as (a) the court determines when the hearing ought to be held and (b) the parties continue briefings on the issue of attorney’s fees.
case_data.summary_short:
In June 2018, unaccompanied immigrant children in the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) custody sued ORR and HHS, of which it is a component agency, in District Court for the Central District of California. Plaintiffs alleged Due Process and Flores Settlement violations due to their continued detainment in ORR custody even though they had parents or other custodians available to receive them, and because ORR administered psychotropic drugs on them without parental consent. In September 2018, the court denied preliminary injunctions for two of the named plaintiffs detained in southern Texas ORR facilities for lack of jurisdiction. The court found that their habeas petitions were properly venued in the Southern District of Texas against the ORR Field Specialists responsible for their care if the plaintiffs were to refile. In November 2018 the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification and denied most of the defendants' motion to dismiss, granting the motion only with regard to the plaintiffs' claims to enforce the Flores Agreement. The parties have been undergoing discovery and settlement negotiations since 2019 but have not yet reached an agreement. In March 2020, during the nationwide outbreak of COVID-19, the plaintiffs requested an order requiring ORR to release children it has already detained for 30 days or transfer them to non-congregate settings; the court denied this request in early April. On March 11, 2022, Judge Gee partially granted and denied both parties' motions for summary judgment, ordering specific actions for the ORR to enhance procedural due process for different classifications of minors in its custody. On August 30, 2022, she issued a preliminary injunction, later slightly modified, mandating the ORR to enact notifications, reviews, and access to counsel according to the laid out terms. By May 3, 2024, following a mutual proposal for settlement, Judge Gee granted the final approval for the settlement of several claims, appointed a monitor to oversee compliance, and outlined terms for future oversight and potential early termination of the agreements. 

In light of new foundational rules from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Administration for Children and Families July 2024, the preliminary injunction was dissolved on July 2, 2024. On July 12, 2024, the defendants then filed a motion to dismiss considering the promulgation of the Foundational Rule and on July 26, 2024, the plaintiffs filed a motion for declaratory judgment. The court denied the defendants’ motion considering the ability for Congress to undo the Foundational Rule. The court, thus, granted the plaintiffs’ motion for declaratory relief and entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on September 16, 2024. The case remains ongoing as the plaintiffs seek to be awarded attorney’s fees and other costs.

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-BFM     Document 447     Filed 09/16/24     Page 1 of 8   Page ID
#:20769
 
1  
2  
3  
4  
5  
6

8 UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
9 CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
10  
11 LUCAS R., et al.,  )  Case No. CV 18-5741-DMG (BFMx) 
12           Plaintiffs,  )   
13       v.  )  ORDER RE DEFENDANTS’ MOTION 
14 XAVIER  BECERRA,  Secretary  of  U.S.)  TO DISMISS, PLAINTIFFS’ MOTION 
15 Department of Health and Human Services,)   FOR DECLARATORY JUDGMENT, 
16 et al.,     )  AND PARTIES’ CROSS-MOTIONS 
17                                         Defendants.  )  FOR FINAL JUDGMENT [440, 441] 
18 ) 
19 ) 
20  
21 Presently before the Court are Defendants’ Motion to Dismiss Plaintiffs’ first 
22 and second claims for relief and Plaintiffs’ Motion for Declaratory Judgment on the 
23 same claims.  [Doc. ## 440 (“Defs.’ MTD”), 441 (“Pls.’ Notice of MDJ”).]  Both sides 
24 also move for entry of final judgment in this action.  The motions are fully briefed.  
25 [Doc. ## 442 (“Pls.’ MDJ & MTD Opp.”), 444 (“Defs.’ MTD Reply & MDJ Opp.”), 
26 445 (“Pls.’ MDJ Reply”).]  The Court held a hearing on September 13, 2024.  For the 
27 reasons set forth below, the Court DENIES Defendants’ MTD, GRANTS Plaintiffs’ 
28 MDJ, and enters final judgment. 
-1- 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-BFM     Document 447     Filed 09/16/24     Page 2 of 8   Page ID
#:20770
 
I. 
1
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND1 
2
3 Class members are unaccompanied non-citizen minors detained by the Office of 
4 Refugee Resettlement (“ORR”) of the Department of Health and Human Services 
5 (“HHS”).  The class members in this action are also class members in the related action, 
6 Flores v. Garland, No. CV 85-4544-DMG (AGRx) (C.D. Cal.).  In this action, the class 
7 challenged ORR’s policies and practices concerning:  (1) the placement of children in 
8 restrictive facilities without adequate notice (the “step-up” claim), (2) the refusal to 
9 release children to family members because the family member was allegedly “unfit” 
10 (the “unfit custodian” claim), (3) the administration of psychotropic medication to 
11 children  without  sufficient  procedural  safeguards  (the  “psychotropic  medications” 
12 claim), (4) the interference with children’s ability to obtain legal assistance with respect 
13 to their custody, placement, and release (the “legal representation” claim), and (5) the 
14 placement of children in restrictive facilities solely because of their disabilities (the 
15 “disability” claim). 
16 On March 11, 2022, the Court granted in part and denied in part the parties’ 
17 cross-motions for summary judgment (“MSJ”).  [Doc. # 376 (“MSJ Order”).]  In doing 
18 so,  the  Court  granted  partial  summary  judgment  to  Plaintiffs  on  the  due  process 
19 allegations of the Step-Up and Unfit Custodian classes and partial summary judgment 
20 to Defendants on the TVPRA2/APA allegations of the same classes.  On August 30, 
21 2022, the Court issued a preliminary injunction to effectuate the MSJ Order.  [Doc. # 
22 391 (“PI”).] 
23
24  
1 A detailed discussion of the factual and procedural background in this matter up until 
25 summary judgment is included in the Court’s March 11, 2022 Summary Judgment Order, and is 
incorporated herein by this reference.  [Doc. # 376 (“Ord. re MSJs”).]  The Court will therefore 
26
provide only an abbreviated version of the background here. 
27  
2 William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008, Pub. L. 
28 No. 110-457 (codified in principal part at 8 U.S.C. § 1232). 
-2- 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-BFM     Document 447     Filed 09/16/24     Page 3 of 8   Page ID
#:20771
 
1 In November 2023, the parties informed the Court that they had reached a partial 
2 settlement and moved for preliminary approval of the settlements on Plaintiffs’ third, 
3 fourth, and fifth claims.  [Doc. # 408 (“MPA”).]  The Court entered final approval of 
4 the settlements on May 3, 2024 and dismissed Plaintiffs’ third, fourth, and fifth claims 
5 for relief.  [Doc. # 433.]  The Court did not enter final judgment on those claims, 
6 however, because the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure disfavor the entry of partial 
7 judgment in an action when all claims have not yet been resolved.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 
8 54(b). 
9 HHS promulgated the Unaccompanied Children Program Foundational Rule 
10 (“Foundational Rule” or “Rule”) in April 2024, and the Rule went into effect on July 
11 1, 2024.  See 89 Fed. Reg. 34,384 (promulgated April 30, 2024) (codified at 45 C.F.R. 
12 pt. 410).  On July 2, 2024, the parties filed, and the Court approved, a Joint Stipulation 
13 to  dissolve  the  Court’s  August  2022  PI,  based  on  the  fact  that  the  Rule  fully 
14 implemented the terms of the Court’s PI.  [Doc. # 438.] 
15 Defendants now move to dismiss Plaintiffs’ remaining two claims, arguing that 
16 they have been rendered moot by the Foundational Rule.  Plaintiffs oppose the motion 
17 to dismiss and request that the Court enter a declaratory judgment incorporating its 
18 March 2022 summary judgment order. 
19
II. 
20 LEGAL STANDARDS 
21 A.  Mootness 
22 A claim becomes moot if it has been remedied independent of the court.  See 
23 Genesis Healthcare Corp. v. Symczyk, 569 U.S. 66, 72 (2013).  Nonetheless, “[i]t is 
24 well settled that ‘a defendant’s voluntary cessation of a challenged practice does not 
25 deprive a federal court of its power to determine the legality of the practice.’”  Friends 
26 of the Earth, Inc. v. Laidlaw Env’t Servs. (TOC), Inc., 528 U.S. 167, 189 (2000) 
27 (quoting City of Mesquite v. Aladdin’s Castle, Inc., 455 U.S. 283, 289 (1982)).  For 
28 voluntary  cessation  to  moot  a  case,  the  defendant  arguing  mootness  “bears  [a] 
-3- 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-BFM     Document 447     Filed 09/16/24     Page 4 of 8   Page ID
#:20772
 
1 formidable  burden  of  showing  that  it  is  absolutely  clear  the  allegedly  wrongful 
2 behavior could not reasonably be expected to recur.”  Id. at 190 (emphasis added).  The 
3 defendant arguing mootness also must show that “any effects of the alleged violation 
4 must be permanently reversed.”  Health Freedom Def. Fund, Inc. v. Carvalho, 104 
5 F.4th 715, 722 (9th Cir. 2024) (citing Los Angeles County v. Davis, 440 U.S. 625, 631 
6 (1979)).  Further, this “formidable burden” “holds for governmental defendants no less 
7 than for private ones.”  Id. (quoting FBI v. Fikre, 601 U.S. 234, 241 (2024)). 
8 B.  Declaratory Relief 
9 Under the Declaratory Judgment Act, courts may only grant declaratory relief to 
10 resolve a “case of actual controversy” between interested parties.  28 U.S.C. § 2201(a).  
11 That phrase refers to the “type of ‘Cases’ and ‘Controversies’ that are justiciable under 
12 Article III.”  See MedImmune, Inc. v. Genentech, Inc., 549 U.S. 118, 127 (2007). 
13 Even  when  a  plaintiff  alleges  sufficient  facts  to  establish  a  justiciable 
14 controversy,  courts  have  the  discretion  to  determine  whether  declaratory  relief  is 
15 necessary or proper.  See 28 U.S.C. 2201; Huth v. Hartford Ins. Co., 298 F.3d 800, 802 
16 (9th Cir. 2002) (“The exercise of jurisdiction under the Federal Declaratory Judgment 
17 Act  .  .  .  is  committed  to  the  sound  discretion  of  the  federal  district  courts.”).  
18 Declaratory relief may be appropriate where:  (1) “the judgment will serve a useful 
19 purpose in clarifying and settling the legal relations in issue, and (2) when it will 
20 terminate and afford relief from the uncertainty, insecurity, and controversy giving rise 
21 to the proceeding.”  Guerra v. Sutton, 783 F.2d 1371, 1376 (9th Cir. 1986) (citation 
22 and internal quotation marks omitted).  Although Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 57 
23 states that “the existence of another adequate remedy does not preclude a declaratory 
24 judgment,” “the availability of other adequate remedies may make declaratory relief 
25 inappropriate[.]”    Fed.  R.  Civ.  P.  57;  United  Safeguard  Distribs.  Ass’n,  Inc.  v. 
26 Safeguard Bus. Sys., Inc., 145 F. Supp. 3d 932, 960–61 (C.D. Cal. 2015). 
   
27
28
-4- 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-BFM     Document 447     Filed 09/16/24     Page 5 of 8   Page ID
#:20773
 
III. 
1
DISCUSSION 
2
A.  Mootness 
3
As a preliminary matter, the Court must address Defendants’ contention that they 
4
are entitled to a “presumption of mootness” pursuant to the Ninth Circuit’s decision in 
5
Board of Trustees of Glazing Health & Welfare Trust v. Chambers.  See 941 F.3d 1195, 
6
1199 (9th Cir. 2019).  In Glazing, the court distinguished between voluntary cessations 
7
by private parties and legislative bodies, concluding that while voluntary cessations by 
8
private parties were unlikely to render a case moot, voluntary cessations by legislative 
9
bodies—via passage of legislation—are entitled to a “presumption of mootness.”  Id.  
10
Here, Defendants argue that they—via implementation of the Foundational Rule—are 
11
entitled to a presumption of mootness on Plaintiffs’ first two claims and that Plaintiffs 
12
therefore bear the burden of overcoming that presumption.  Defs.’ MTD at 19.3 
13
This argument fails for two reasons.  First, ORR, the agency responsible for the 
14
Foundational Rule, is not a “legislative body.”  See Ernst & Ernst v. Hochfelder, 425 
15
U.S. 185, 213 (1976) (“The rulemaking power granted to an administrative agency . . . 
16
is not the power to make law.”).  Second, Glazing was decided prior to the Supreme 
17
Court’s decision in Fikre, where the Court explained that “governmental defendants” 
18
bear the same “formidable burden” as private defendants when attempting to prove 
19
mootness.  See Fikre, 601 U.S. at 241.  Although the Supreme Court did not address 
20
Glazing in its Fikre decision, there is at least some tension between the two opinions.  
21
See  Chang  v.  Cnty  of  Siskiyou,  ---  F.  Supp.  3d  ---  (E.D.  Cal.  Aug.  21,  2024).  
22
Nonetheless, to the extent the Court must resolve this tension in order to reach a 
23
decision here, the Court finds it possible to harmonize the two by interpreting Glazing 
24
to apply to legislative bodies (e.g., state legislatures, Congress) and Fikre to apply to 
25
other government entities (e.g., executive or agency action)—but in both instances, the 
26
overarching  consideration  is  whether  there  is  a  reasonable  expectation  that  the 
27
 
28 3 Page citations herein refer to the page numbers inserted by the CM/ECF system. 
-5- 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-BFM     Document 447     Filed 09/16/24     Page 6 of 8   Page ID
#:20774
 
1 challenged action or conduct or something similar will not recur.  Defendants are not 
2 entitled to a presumption of mootness under the circumstances of this case, where the 
3 regulation has been in place for little more than two months and already there has been 
4 an effort on the part of some members of Congress to undermine it. 
5    Without a presumption of mootness, Defendants are unable to overcome their 
6 “formidable” burden because it is not clear that “[all] effects of the alleged violation[s] 
7 [are] permanently reversed.”  See Health Freedom, 104 F.4th at 722 (emphasis added).  
8 Although the Court commends Defendants on the promulgation of the Foundational 
9 Rule, it is nonetheless true that the Rule’s “permanence” is not guaranteed at this time.  
10 See Pls.’ MDJ Reply at 8.  The Court assumes the Government has “act[ed] in good 
11 faith,”  but  through  no  fault  of  Defendants’,  46  senators  have  introduced  a  joint 
12 resolution  pursuant  to  the  Congressional  Review  Act  (“CRA”)  providing  for 
13 congressional disapproval of the Foundational Rule. See Rosebrock v. Mathis, 745 F.3d 
14 963, 974 (9th Cir. 2014).  Although Defendants attempt to downplay the significance 
15 of the CRA, if the CRA joint disapproval were approved by both houses of Congress 
16 and signed by the President, the Rule could be wholly terminated or prevented from 
17 being given its full effect.  See 5 U.S.C. § 802.  If this occurred after the Court’s 
18 dismissal of Plaintiffs’ first two claims, minors in ORR custody would be left without 
19 the important protections they recently obtained in this case.4  Thus, with the CRA 
20 resolution pending, the Court cannot conclude that it is “absolutely clear” that there is 
21 no reasonable expectation of recurrence.   
22   In light of the foregoing, the Court DENIES Defendants’ MTD. 
23
 
4  The  Court  employed  a  similar  reasoning  in  its  recent  Flores  decision  conditionally 
24
terminating the Flores Settlement Agreement (“FSA”) as to HHS, in light of the Foundational Rule:  
25 “If  the  Court  relinquishes  jurisdiction  over  HHS  due  to  the  Foundational  Rule  and  Congress 
subsequently enacts this joint resolution, Flores class members in ORR custody could be left without 
26
any protections—which would be contrary to the terms of the FSA.  The Court’s termination of the 
27 FSA as to HHS is therefore conditional on there not being a recission of those regulations, such as 
the Foundational Rule, in a manner inconsistent with the FSA.”  Flores v. Garland,  No. CV 85-4544-
28 DMG (AGRx), 2024 WL 3467715 at *9 (C.D. Cal. June 28, 2024). 
-6- 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-BFM     Document 447     Filed 09/16/24     Page 7 of 8   Page ID
#:20775
 
1 B.  Declaratory Relief 
2 Because the Court does not find Plaintiffs’ first two claims to have been rendered 
3 moot by the Foundational Rule, it is within the Court’s discretion whether to grant 
4 declaratory relief to Plaintiffs.  See Flast v. Cohen, 392 U.S. 83, 95 (1968) (explaining 
5 that declaratory relief is inappropriate for moot issues).  Plaintiffs admit that so long as 
6 the Foundational Rule is in place, their requested declaratory relief would function as 
7 little more than backup in ensuring children in ORR custody are afforded the rights to 
8 which they are entitled.  Pls.’ MDJ & MTD Opp. at 24–25.  Because the Rule could be 
9 terminated or weakened—via the proposed CRA resolution or otherwise—declaratory 
10 judgment would “serve a useful purpose in clarifying and settling the legal relations in 
11 issue.”  See Guerra, 783 F.2d at 1376.  The Foundational Rule is an impressive 
12 achievement by all parties in this action and the Flores action, and it will hopefully 
13 provide critical protections to non-citizen children for generations to come.  It is 
14 nonetheless  true  that  in  the  absence  of  the  Rule  or  the  Court’s  now-dissolved 
15 preliminary injunction, Plaintiffs would once again find themselves and their rights 
16 back at square one, and Defendants could land back in court in the future, re-litigating 
17 many of the same issues.  Given the past six years of hard-fought litigation, that would 
18 be  an  undesirable  result.  The  Court  therefore  concludes  that  declaratory  relief  is 
19 appropriate  here  in  order  to  “afford  relief  from  the  uncertainty,  insecurity,  and 
20 controversy giving rise to the proceeding.”  See id; see also Rosebrock, 745 F.3d at 974 
21 (describing  the  potential  utility  of  a  declaratory  judgment  if  the  “objectionable 
22 conduct” could recur in the future, but denying injunctive relief for mootness). 
23 The  Court  GRANTS  Plaintiffs’  motion  for  declaratory  judgment,  which 
24 amounts to nothing more than memorializing in a final judgment what the Court 
25 already articulated in its MSJ Order. 
   
26
27
28
-7- 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-BFM     Document 447     Filed 09/16/24     Page 8 of 8   Page ID
#:20776
1 C. Final Judgment 
2 All claims in this action have now been resolved—claims one and two through 
3 summary judgment and claims three, four, and five through settlement.  It is now 
4 appropriate to enter a final judgment to resolve this action. 
5
IV. 
6 CONCLUSION 
7 In light of the foregoing, Defendants’ Motion to Dismiss Plaintiffs’ first and 
8 second claims for relief is DENIED, Plaintiffs’ Motion for Declaratory Judgment 
9 regarding their first and second claims for relief is GRANTED, and the Court will 
10 enter final judgment in this action consistent with the following: 
11
1. In entering final judgment, the Court hereby INCORPORATES its findings and 
12
legal conclusions in the MSJ Order entered March 11, 2022, with respect to 
13
Plaintiffs’ first claim for relief on behalf of the “unfit custodian class” and second 
14
claim for relief on behalf of the “step-up class.”  See MSJ Order [Doc. # 376].
15
2. Regarding Plaintiffs’ “psychotropic medications,” “legal representation,” and 
16
“disability” claims, as provided in the Parties’ Agreements and approved by the 
17
Court on May 3, 2024, “the Court will retain jurisdiction over its judgment and 
18
[Approval  Order]  only  for  the  purposes  of  interpreting  and  enforcing  the 
19
Agreements until the Termination Dates, as set forth in the Agreements.”  See 
20
Approval Order at 3 [Doc. # 433]. 
21
IT IS SO ORDERED. 
22
23
DATED:  September 16, 2024    _____________________________________ 
24
            DOLLY M. GEE 
25             CHIEF UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE 
26
27
28
-8-

1 PREAMBLE
2 This Settlement Agreement (“Agreement”) is entered into by all Plaintiffs and 
3 Defendants in this class action lawsuit (collectively “the Parties”). Plaintiffs and class 
4 representatives Lucas R., Daniela Marisol T., Gabriela N., Jaime D., Sirena P., and 
5 Benjamin F. are or were children formerly in the custody of the Office of Refugee 
6 Resettlement (“ORR”) of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services 
7 (“HHS”).  Defendants are the Secretary of HHS and the Director of ORR, both of 
8 whom are sued in their respective official capacities.
9 WHEREAS Plaintiffs filed this lawsuit challenging, inter alia, Defendants’ 
10 policies and practices with respect to the administration of psychotropic drugs to 
11 minors in ORR’s care and custody; 
12 WHEREAS the District Court certified this case as a class action on behalf of, 
13 inter alia, all minors in ORR custody pursuant to 6 U.S.C. § 279 and/or 8 U.S.C. § 
14 1232 who are or will be prescribed or administered one or more Psychotropic 
15 Medications without procedural safeguards; 
16 WHEREAS Exhibit 1 to the class-wide settlement in Flores v. Barr, No. CV85-
17 4454-DMG (C.D. Cal.), as currently in effect, requires that licensed programs 
18 “comply with all applicable state child welfare laws and regulations. . .”; 
19 WHEREAS on July 30, 2018, the District Court ordered “Defendants to comply 
20 with all Texas child welfare laws and regulations governing the administration of 
21 psychotropic drugs to Class Members at Shiloh RTC” (July 30, 2018 Order at 23); 
22 WHEREAS the Parties agree: (a) that Psychotropic Medications should be used 
23 to treat psychiatric conditions only following a diagnostic assessment by a licensed 
24 healthcare provider and considering other situational factors that may be contributing 
25 to the condition (i.e., trauma); (b) that Psychotropic Medications should be aligned 
26 with the child’s diagnosis (i.e., the medication is appropriately used on- or off-label to 
27 treat the child’s specific diagnosis and not used due to other therapies being 
28 inconvenient or more expensive, recognizing that payment systems may utilize 
4
STIPULATED SETTLEMENT
CASE NO.2:18-CV-05741DMGPLA
Exhibit A 
Page 5

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 408-3   Filed 11/14/23   Page 6 of 48   Page ID
#:20028
1 formularies); (c) that Psychotropic Medications should be administered only in 
2 accordance with a licensed prescriber’s recommendation based upon the minor’s 
3 symptoms and periodically reassessed by a licensed prescriber for side-effects and 
4 benefits; (d) that recognizing that Psychotropic Medications may be prescribed off-
5 label, Psychotropic Medications should be administered at dosages that do not exceed 
6 dosing guidelines that recommend a specific dose based upon age and weight where 
7 dosing guidelines are available; and (e) that Psychotropic Medications shall never be 
8 used as punishment for disruptive or inappropriate behavior, for the convenience of 
9 staff members or caregivers, or as a substitute for adequate staffing and/or adequate 
10 ongoing programming for a child’s needs; 
11 WHEREAS the Parties have conducted discussions and negotiations in good

4 child’s needs in lieu of administration of emergency medication. This 
5 emergency exception may not be relied upon for the routine or ongoing 
6 administration of Psychotropic Medication(s) to a UC. 
7 B. ORR shall require all Care Providers to follow existing ORR policies 
8 regarding the use of chemical restraints on any UC.  In addition, ORR shall 
9 maintain a policy requiring that use of any chemical restraint must terminate 
10 when the emergency situation has ended, and be documented as a 
11 Significant Incident Report within twenty-four hours.  Any Care Provider 
12 that has a pattern of using chemical restraints (defined as three or more uses 
13 on the same child while placed with the Care Provider or five or more uses
14 on any child within 30 days), shall be flagged for DHUC for follow up, 
15 training, and monitoring by ORR.

3 VIII. ROLE OF CENTRALIZED CONCURRENCE UNIT (CCU)
4 A. ORR will enter into an agreement with an entity to act as the CCU and will 
5 require as part of the agreement that the CCU acquire the services of at least 
6 one licensed psychiatrist, with a preference for a licensed child and 
7 adolescent psychiatrist when available, to oversee responsibilities; however, 
8 ORR may rely on a psychiatrist within DHUC to act as the CCU.  
9 B. The CCU shall have the following responsibilities:
10 1. Provide or withhold concurrence to Psychotropic Medication 
11 prescriptions as provided herein where informed consent cannot be 
12 otherwise obtained, as specified in this Agreement.  
13 2. Override denial of consent, as specified in Section IV of this 
14 Agreement.
15 3. Document and track its work relating to Sections VIII.B.1 and 2 
16 above and provide such information to the Monitor for inclusion in 
17 her reports.
18 C. Nothing in this Agreement requires that ORR/DHUC or the CCU override 
19 the state medical licensing standards under which licensed psychiatrists 
20 (and/or child and adolescent psychiatrists) operate.  If a CCU psychiatrist 
21 notifies ORR that their state license is at risk based on implementing any of 
22 the provisions of the policies adopted pursuant to this Agreement, ORR will 
23 ensure that the Monitor is notified of the conflict within ten days of 
24 discovering such conflict and will provide the Monitor with ORR’s proposed 
25 plan to ensure substantial compliance with this Agreement with respect to 
26 UCs housed within the State. The Monitor may share this information with 
27 Plaintiffs’ counsel at the Monitor’s discretion, as is consistent with VII.E.1.

3 Plaintiffs’ Third Claim for Relief, and supersedes all prior agreements, 
4 representations, warranties, statements, promises, covenants, and 
5 understandings, whether oral or written, express or implied, with respect to 
6 the subject matter thereof.
7 B. This Agreement is an integrated agreement at the time of authorization and 
8 may not be altered, amended, or modified except in writing executed by 
9 Plaintiffs and Defendants.
10 XVIII. MUTUAL EXCLUSIVITY OF PROVISIONS
11 A. If any provision of this Agreement is declared invalid, illegal, or 
12 unenforceable in any respect, the remaining provisions shall remain in full 
13 force and effect, unaffected and unimpaired.
14 XIX. MULTIPLE COUNTERPARTS
15 A. This Agreement may be executed in a number of identical counterparts, all 
16 of which shall constitute one agreement, and such execution may be 
17 evidenced by signatures delivered electronically.
18 XX. TITLES AND HEADINGS
19 A. Titles and headings to Articles and Sections herein are inserted for 
20 convenience and reference only and are not intended to be part of, or to 
21 affect the meaning or interpretation of, this Agreement.
22 XXI. REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTY
23 A. Counsel for the Parties, on behalf of themselves and their clients, represent 
24 that they know of nothing in this Agreement that exceeds the legal authority 
25 of the Parties or is in violation of any law. Defendants’ counsel represent 
26 and warrant that they are fully authorized and empowered to enter into this 
27 Agreement on behalf of the Secretary of the HHS and acknowledge that 
28 Plaintiffs enter into this Agreement in reliance on such representation.

1 I.  INTRODUCTION 
2 Plaintiffs seek judicially-created policies and procedures regarding the care of 
3 unaccompanied alien children (UACs) in Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) 
4 custody  under  a  procedural-due-process  theory  that  exceed  both  what  they 
5 previously negotiated in a nationwide settlement agreement and what Congress has 
6 mandated  by  statute.  These  additional  procedures  would  alter  the  policies  and 
7 procedures that ORR follows in making three vital decisions to safeguard the welfare 
8 of UACs entrusted to its legal custody: (1) where UACs are housed; (2) when and 
9 how they are released; and (3) the services they receive while in federal custody.  
10 Two of the plaintiff classes in this case—the step-up class and the unfit-custodian 
11 class—challenge  the  policies  and  procedures  ORR  follows  in  making  those 
12 decisions.  A third plaintiff class—the legal representation class—seeks additional 
13 services not provided by Congress to contest those decisions.  Each class’s claims 
14 fail as a matter of law.  To start, their challenges were conclusively resolved in Flores 
15 v. Barr, No. 85-cv-04544, where this Court approved a settlement agreement (the 
16 Flores Settlement or Settlement) that “set[ ] out nationwide policy for the detention, 
17 release, and treatment of minors in the custody of the INS” (¶ 9) for “[a]ll minors 
18 who are detained in the legal custody of the INS” (¶ 10).  Even if these claims were 
19 not barred by res judicata, ORR’s procedures satisfy due process as a matter of law 
20 and withstand all of Plaintiffs’ other challenges.  This Court should therefore grant 
21 summary judgment for Defendants under Fed. R. Civ. P. 56 on those three classes’ 
22 claims. 
23 First, the Court should grant summary judgment for Defendants on the step-
24 up class’s claim that ORR does not provide adequate notice and an opportunity to 
25 be heard for UACs who are placed in a secure, staff-secure, or residential-treatment-
26 center facility within 30 days of a step-up to those facilities.  The step-up claim is 
27 barred by res judicata.  The Flores Settlement conclusively resolved the question of 
28 what procedures due process requires be provided to UACs who wish to challenge 
1 
Memorandum in Support of Motion for Summary Judgment 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 263-1   Filed 10/02/20   Page 10 of 69   Page ID
#:5748
 
1 ORR  placement  decisions.  Under  the  Settlement,  a  minor  may  seek  “a  bond 
2 redetermination  hearing  before  an  immigration  judge”  (¶ 24A)  to  determine 
3 dangerousness or whether they are a flight risk, and “[a]ny minor who disagrees with 
4 the INS’s determination to place that minor in a particular type of facility . . . may 
5 seek judicial review in any United States District Court with jurisdiction and venue 
6 over the matter to challenge that placement determination” (¶24B).  The step-up 
7 class’s claim involves substantially the same evidence, alleges infringement of the 
8 same rights, and arises out of the same transactional nucleus of facts as the Flores 
9 Settlement.  Under settled principles of res judicata, the Settlement precludes the 
10 step-up  class  from  raising  a  new  procedural  due  process  claim  to  seek  new 
11 procedures not required under the Settlement for this class, and imposing such 
12 procedures would deprive Defendants of the benefits that they negotiated under the 
13 Settlement.   
14 Even if res judicata did not bar the step-up class’s claim, the Court should still 
15 grant summary judgment to Defendants because ORR’s policies and procedures for 
16 that class satisfy due process as a matter of law under Mathews v. Eldridge, 424 U.S. 
17 319 (1976).  Children, unlike adults, are always in some form of custody, and so 
18 their liberty interest is limited.  UACs in particular are children who lack an available 
19 care provider, and Congress has expressly granted custody of UACs to ORR.  ORR, 
20 in turn, has developed and follows extensive procedures when placing a UAC in a 
21 more restrictive setting.  Those procedures include multiple levels of review and 
22 opportunities to be heard, and balance important interests such as placing a child in 
23 the least restrictive setting appropriate for the child’s needs while also providing for 
24 the  safety  and  welfare  of  other  children  in  ORR  care.    Additional  procedures 
25 allowing  further  challenges  to  routine  child-welfare  decision-making  in  an 
26 adversarial proceeding would not meaningfully reduce the (already low) risk of 
27 erroneous  deprivation  of  the  class  members’  diminished  liberty  interest. 
28
2 
Memorandum in Support of Motion for Summary Judgment 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 263-1   Filed 10/02/20   Page 11 of 69   Page ID
#:5749
 
1 Accordingly, under Mathews, Defendants are entitled to judgment as a matter of law 
2 on the step-up class’s due-process claim.   
3 Defendants are also entitled to judgment as a matter of law on the step-up 
4 class’s claim that ORR’s policies and procedures on custody decisions violate the 
5 Trafficking  Victims  Protection  Reauthorization  Act  (TVPRA)  and  the 
6 Administrative Procedure Act (APA).  Plaintiffs identify no provision under either 
7 statute that mandates the procedures they seek, and their claim under both statutes is 
8 simply their procedural-due-process claim recast as a statutory violation.  So their 
9 claims under the TVPRA and the APA fail as a matter of law.   
10 Second, the Court should grant summary judgment for Defendants on the 
11 unfit-custodian class’s claim that ORR does not provide a timely and meaningful 
12 opportunity to be heard when ORR delays or denies release to potential sponsors.  
13 Plaintiffs’  unfit-custodian  claim  is  barred  by  res  judicata  because  the  Flores 
14 Settlement conclusively resolved what procedures due process requires for release 
15 decisions.  The Settlement requires ORR to avoid “unnecessary delay” in releasing 
16 minors from its custody (¶ 14), sets forth criteria for ORR to consider in making a 
17 suitability determination for potential sponsors (¶ 17), requires ORR to “make” and 
18 “record” release efforts (¶ 18), and sets forth a procedure for a UAC’s attorney to 
19 contact a “juvenile coordinator” to “investigate” any case where “Plaintiffs’ counsel 
20 have reasonable cause to believe a minor . . . should have been released” (¶ 28B).  
21 The unfit-custodian class’s claim involves substantially the same evidence, alleges 
22 infringement of the same rights, and arises out of the same transactional nucleus of 
23 facts as Flores, which set forth “nationwide policy for the detention, release, and 
24 treatment of minors in the custody of the INS” (¶ 9).  Res judicata thus precludes a 
25 new due-process claim like this one that seeks additional procedures for minors in 
26 immigration custody on claims that could have been raised in Flores.   
27 Even if res judicata did not bar the unfit-custodian class’s claim, the Court 
28 should still grant summary judgment for Defendants because ORR’s policies and 
3

1 procedures regarding release satisfy due process as a matter of law.  As with the 
2 step-up  class,  the  unfit-custodian  class’s  liberty  interest  is  limited  given  class 
3 members’ status as children and as UACs apprehended at the border without legal 
4 immigration status.  And ORR has developed and follows extensive procedures 
5 involving multiple levels of review in determining whether to release a UAC to a 
6 potential sponsor.  These processes safeguard the welfare of children in ORR’s care 
7 while affording both children and potential sponsors ample opportunities to present 
8 information supporting release.  These processes, which appropriately balance the 
9 competing interests involved in release decisions in a safe and timely manner, satisfy 
10 due process as a matter of law.   
11 Defendants are further entitled to judgment as a matter of law on the unfit-
12 custodian class’s claim that ORR’s policies and procedures for release decisions 
13 violate the TVPRA, the APA, and the First Amendment.  Plaintiffs identify no 
14 provision under either the TVPRA or the APA that mandates the procedures they 
15 seek, and their claims under both statutes are simply their procedural-due-process 
16 claims recast as statutory violations.  Similarly, Plaintiffs’ claim under the First 
17 Amendment fails as a matter of law because it is simply their flawed due-process 
18 claim recast under the First Amendment’s Freedom of Association Clause, which 
19 does not help them in this context.   
20 Finally, the Court should grant summary judgment for Defendants on the 
21 legal-representation class’s claim that ORR “blocks” lawyers from representing 
22 class  members  in  matters  involving  ORR’s  custody,  release,  medication,  and 
23 placement  decisions.    The  legal-representation  class’s  claim  that  due  process 
24 requires ORR to facilitate access to counsel to contest routine ORR decisionmaking 
25 is barred by res judicata.  The Flores Settlement conclusively resolved this issue: 
26 for legal representation, the Settlement expressly provides that UACs must receive 
27 information regarding the “right to be represented by counsel at no expense to the 
28 government,” but articulates no other requirements for facilitation beyond providing

#:5751
 
1 “[l]egal services information regarding the availability of free legal assistance” (Ex. 
2 1, ¶ 14).  Like the claims of the step-up and unfit-custodian classes, the legal-
3 representation  class’s  claim  involves  substantially  the  same  evidence,  alleges 
4 infringement of the same rights, and arises out of the same transactional nucleus of 
5 facts as Flores.  Res judicata therefore precludes Plaintiffs’ due process claim 
6 seeking additional legal-representation entitlements for class members beyond those 
7 provided in the Flores Settlement.   
8 Summary  judgment  for  Defendants  is  also  warranted  on  the  legal-
9 representation class’s claim, even if res judicata did not apply, because ORR’s 
10 policies and procedures regarding legal representation of UACs satisfy due process.  
11 There  is  no  protected  liberty  interest  in  Plaintiffs’  claimed  right  to  access 
12 representation by ORR-funded legal service providers to challenge ORR’s step-up, 
13 release,  and  medication  decisions.    Challenges  to  routine  child-welfare 
14 decisionmaking have never been interpreted to mean “legal proceedings or matters” 
15 under § 235(c)(5) of the TVPRA, and there is no evidence that ORR blocks legal 
16 service providers from using non-ORR funds to independently represent UACs.  
17 And even if there were some minimal interest, any risk of erroneous deprivation is 
18 low given ORR’s extensive policies and procedures to ensure that UACs can obtain 
19 information about the ability “to be represented by counsel at no expense to the 
20 government” (Ex. 1, ¶ 14).   
21 Defendants are also entitled to judgment as a matter of law on the legal-
22 representation  class’s  claim  that  ORR’s  policies  and  procedures  for  legal 
23 representation of UACs contravene the TVPRA, the Homeland Security Act (HSA), 
24 federal immigration regulations, and the APA.  None of these statute and regulations 
25 mandate  the  right  to  access  government-funded  counsel  to  represent  UACs  in 
26 matters unrelated to immigration proceedings, government-funded or not, nor do the 
27 uncontroverted facts show that ORR blocks attorneys of record from representing 
28 their clients.  Thus, Plaintiffs’ legal-representation claims fail as a matter of law.

3 II.  RELEVANT BACKGROUND 
4 The Flores Litigation and Its Resolution of Issues for UACs.  Flores v. Barr, 
5 No. 85-cv-04544 (C.D. Cal.), was filed in 1985.  The Flores plaintiffs brought suit 
6
on behalf of a class of certain alien minors detained by the INS because “a parent or 
7
legal guardian [had] fail[ed] to personally appear to take custody of them.”  Reno v. 
8
Flores, 507 U.S. 292, 296 (1993).  In 1986, the district court certified two classes:  
9
(1) All persons under the age of eighteen (18) years who have been, 
10 are, or will be arrested and detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. § 1252 by 
[INS] within the INS’ Western Region and who have been, are, or 
11
will be denied release from INS custody because a parent or legal 
12 guardian fails to personally appear to take custody of them; and 
(2) All persons under the age of eighteen (18) who have been, are or 
13
will be arrested and detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. § 1252 by [INS] 
14
within the INS’ Western Region and who have been, are, or will be 
15 subjected  to  any  of  the  following  conditions:  a.  inadequate 
opportunities for exercise or recreation; b. inadequate educational 
16
instruction;  c.  inadequate  reading  materials;  d.  inadequate 
17 opportunities  for  visitation  with  counsel,  family,  and  friends; 
e. regular contact as a result of confinement with adult detainees 
18
unrelated to such minors either by blood, marriage, or otherwise; 
19
f. strip or body cavity search after meeting with counsel or at any 
20 other time or occasion absent demonstrable adequate cause.  
21
Flores v. Lynch, 828 F.3d 898, 902 (9th Cir. 2016).  In May 1988, the INS published 
22
rules governing the detention and release of juveniles, 53 Fed. Reg. 17449, which 
23
the Supreme Court upheld.  Flores, 507 U.S. at 315.  The Supreme Court held that 
24
the new rules were a “reasonable response to the difficult problems presented when 
25
the [INS] arrests unaccompanied alien juveniles” and “accord[ed] with both the 
26
Constitution and the relevant statute.”  Id. at 315. 
27
28
6
