1 In 1997, the Flores district court approved a settlement agreement between 
2 the federal government and a class of “[a]ll minors who are detained in the legal 
3
custody of the INS” (¶ 10).  The Settlement “sets out nationwide policy for the 
4
detention, release, and treatment of minors in the custody of the INS” (¶ 9) and 
5
provides detailed procedures and standards for the release and placement of UACs 
6
in federal custody (Ex. 1).  The Settlement states that “upon execution of this 
7
Agreement in their representative capacities, the principals, agents, and successors 
8
of such principals and agents shall be fully and unequivocally bound hereunder to 
9
the full extent authorized by law” (¶ 41). 
10
On placement of UACs in federal custody, the Settlement provides that “[a] 
11
minor may be held in or transferred to a suitable State or county juvenile detention 
12
facility” whenever the relevant agency official “determines that the minor” has met 
13
certain criteria, including being chargeable with a crime, making credible threats of 
14
violence, engaging in unacceptably disruptive behavior, or being an escape risk 
15
(¶ 21).  The Settlement additionally allows challenges to certain agency custodial 
16
decisions: it specifies procedures for a bond hearing before an immigration judge 
17
(¶ 24A), allows for judicial review in a court with jurisdiction and venue to challenge 
18
placement in a particular type of facility, such as a secure facility (¶ 24B), and 
19
articulates an “abuse of discretion” standard of review for such placements (¶ 24C).  
20
It also delegates review and approvals of placements in secure facilities to agency 
21
personnel and does not require further process within the agency (¶ 23).  
22
On release, the Settlement provides that release shall be considered only 
23
where the agency “determines that detention . . . is not required . . . to secure . . . 
24
appearance before the . . . immigration court, or to ensure the minor’s safety or that 
25
of others.”  In such a case, the agency “shall release a minor from its custody without 
26
unnecessary delay” to an approved custodian (¶ 14), and the agency “shall make and 
27
record the prompt and continuous efforts on its part toward . . . release” (¶ 18).  The 
28
7 
Memorandum in Support of Motion for Summary Judgment 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 263-1   Filed 10/02/20   Page 16 of 69   Page ID
#:5754
 
1 Settlement also provides the agency with broad authority to conduct suitability 
2 determinations  of  potential  custodians,  which  “may”  include  a  number  of 
3 “components,” before releasing a class member (¶ 17).  The Settlement specifies that 
4 if “Plaintiffs’ counsel have reasonable cause to believe that a minor in INS legal 
5 custody should have been released pursuant to Paragraph 14, Plaintiffs’ counsel may 
6 contact the Juvenile Coordinator to request that the Coordinator investigate the case 
7 and inform Plaintiffs’ counsel of the reasons why the minor has not been released” 
8 (¶ 28B).  
9 Finally, the Settlement provides that UACs are to be provided with a list of 
10 free legal services that may be available to them, and that UACs in licensed programs 
11 should be informed of their “right to be represented by counsel at no expense to the 
12 government” (¶ 24D; Ex. 1, ¶ 14).  The Settlement provides no right to counsel, 
13 government-funded or not. 
14 Legislative Developments to Address UACs.  In 2002, Congress enacted the 
15 HSA, Pub. L. No. 107-296, 116 Stat. 2135 (codified in relevant part at 6 U.S.C. 
16 § 279).  The HSA abolished the INS, established the Department of Homeland 
17 Security (DHS), and transferred several functions with respect to the care of UACs 
18 from the INS to ORR, an office within the Department of Health and Human 
19 Services (HHS).  6 U.S.C. §§ 279(a), (b)(1)(A), (g)(2).  Under the HSA, ORR is 
20 responsible for the care and placement of UACs who enter the United States illegally 
21 and  who  are  “in  Federal  custody  by  reason  of  their  immigration  status.”    Id. 
22 § 279(b)(1)(A).  The HSA charges ORR with “coordinating and implementing the 
23 care  and  placement  of  unaccompanied  alien  children,”  “ensuring  that  the  best 
24 interests of the child are considered in decisions and actions relating to the care and 
25 custody of an unaccompanied alien child,” and identifying “a sufficient number of 
26 qualified individuals, entities, and facilities to house” such children.  Id. § 279(b)(1). 
27 The HSA provides that ORR “shall not release” unaccompanied minor children 
28 “upon their own recognizance.”  6 U.S.C. § 279(b)(2)(B).  The HSA includes a 
8 
Memorandum in Support of Motion for Summary Judgment 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 263-1   Filed 10/02/20   Page 17 of 69   Page ID
#:5755
 
1 savings clause that preserves “administrative actions” to which INS was a party, id. 
2 § 552(a)(1) (incorporated by reference in 6 U.S.C. § 279(f)(2)), which has been read 
3 to include the Flores Settlement.   
4 In 2008, the TVPRA was enacted, Pub. L. No. 110-457, 122 Stat. 5044 
5 (principally codified in relevant part at 8 U.S.C. § 1232), “to enhance the efforts of 
6 the United States to prevent trafficking in persons,” to reflect Congress’s goal of 
7 ensuring that UACs “are safely repatriated to their country of nationality or of last 
8 habitual residence,” and to avoid incentives that would lead to alien smuggling and 
9 dangerous travel for minor children.  8 U.S.C. § 1232(a).  The TVPRA defines a 
10 UAC as a person under age 18 who lacks lawful immigration status in the United 
11 States and for whom (a) no parent or legal guardian is in the United States, or (b) no 
12 parent or legal guardian is available to provide care and physical custody.  8 U.S.C. 
13 § 1232(g); see also 6 U.S.C. § 279(g)(2).  Under the TVPRA, UACs from countries 
14 not contiguous to the United States and certain UACs from contiguous countries are 
15 placed into HHS custody.  See 8 U.S.C. §§ 1232(a)(3)-(4), (a)(5)(D), (d)(8).  The 
16 TVPRA further directs HHS to place UACs “in the least restrictive setting that is in 
17 the best interest of the child,” 8 U.S.C. § 1232(c)(2)(A), while the UAC is in HHS 
18 ORR custody—that is, until the UAC is released to a suitable sponsor, obtains lawful 
19 status, or leaves the country, see 6 U.S.C. § 279(g); 8 U.S.C §§ 1232(b)(1), (g).  In 
20 placing children in the least restrictive setting that is in the child’s best interests, 
21 HHS is to “consider danger to self, danger to the community, and risk of flight.”  8 
22 U.S.C. § 1232(c)(2)(A).  Organizations that provide shelter and services to UACs 
23 do so with substantial ORR involvement pursuant to a cooperative agreement with 
24 ORR, see 31 U.S.C. § 6305, and must comply with ORR’s policies and procedures.

26 Regarding Motion and Cross-Motion for Summary Judgment (J.S.) ¶ 93.

5 IV.  LEGAL STANDARD FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
6 “The court shall grant summary judgment if the movant shows that there is no 
7 genuine dispute as to any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a 
8 matter of law.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(a).  The moving party has the initial burden of 
9 demonstrating the absence of any genuine issue of material fact.  Devereaux v. 
10 Abbey, 263 F.3d 1070, 1076 (9th Cir. 2001).  A fact is material if it may affect the 
11 outcome of the case.  Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986).  
12 “Once the moving party carries its initial burden,” the non-moving party  must 
13 provide evidence that “set[s] forth specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue 
14 for trial.”  Devereaux, 263 F.3d. at 1076 (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(e)). 
15 At summary judgment, the Court should draw evidentiary inferences in the 
16 light most favorable to the non-moving party.  King Cty. v. Rasmussen, 299 F.3d 
17 1077, 1083 (9th Cir. 2002).  But the moving party need not disprove matters on 
18 which the opponent has the burden of proof at trial.  Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 
19 U.S. 317, 322 (1986).  Summary judgment is appropriate “against a party who fails 
20 to make a showing sufficient to establish the existence of an element essential to the 
21 party’s case, and on which that party will bear the burden of proof at trial.”  Id. at 
22 322.  “Only disputes over facts that might affect the outcome of the suit under the 
23 governing law will properly preclude the entry of summary judgment.”  Anderson, 
24 477 U.S. at 248. 
25 To create a genuine issue of material fact, a party must rely on facts, not 
26 unsupported statements.  McSherry v. City of Long Beach, 584 F.3d 1129, 1138 (9th 
27 Cir. 2009).  “[O]nly admissible evidence may be considered by the trial court in 
28 ruling on a motion for summary judgment.”  Beyene v. Coleman Sec. Servs., Inc., 
13 
Memorandum in Support of Motion for Summary Judgment

#:5760
 
1 854 F.2d 1179, 1181 (9th Cir. 1988).  To defeat a motion for summary judgment, 
2 the  non-moving  party  must  present  “evidence  on  which  the  [factfinder]  could 
3 reasonably find for the” non-moving party.  Liberty Lobby, 477 U.S. at 252.  Thus, 
4 where the record taken as a whole could not lead a rational trier of fact to find for 
5 the non-moving party, there is no genuine issue for trial and summary judgment is 
6 appropriate.  Matsushita Elec. Indus. Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp., 475 U.S. 574, 587 
7 (1986).

7 a.  Private interests 
8
To start, the private interests that Plaintiffs allege have limited force as applied 
9
to ORR step-up decisions.  Plaintiffs contend that minors in ORR care have two 
10
protected liberty interests that are relevant to the step-up claim: (1) a statutory 
11
interest  under  the  TVPRA  and  a  related  contractual  interest  under  the  Flores 
12
Settlement to be placed in the “least restrictive setting”; and (2) a due-process 
13
interest in being free from “unnecessary physical restraints, including placement in 
14
RTCs, medium-secure or secure facilities.”  Comp. ¶¶ 117-19, 122.  Both interests 
15
have limited weight as applied to Plaintiffs’ step-up claim and, as explained below, 
16
are decisively outweighed by the other Mathews factors. 
17
First, Plaintiffs have at most a limited interest under the TVPRA in placement 
18
“in the least restrictive setting that is in the best interest of the child.”  8 U.S.C. 
19
§ 1232(c)(2)(A).    A  statute  creates  a  protected  liberty  interest  only  when  it: 
20
(1) establishes “‘substantive predicates’ to govern official decision-making,” and 
21
(2) uses  “‘explicitly  mandatory  language,’  i.e.,  specific  directives  to  the 
22
decisionmaker that if the regulations’ substantive predicates are present, a particular 
23
outcome must follow.”  Kentucky Dep’t of Corrections v. Thompson, 490 U.S. 454, 
24
462-63  (1989)  (internal  citations  omitted).  Even  if  the  TVPRA  establishes 
25
“substantive predicates”—i.e., that a UAC “shall be promptly placed in the least 
26
restrictive setting that is in the best interest of the child,” subject to considerations 
27
of “danger to self, danger to the community, and risk of flight”—it contains no 
28
“explicitly mandatory language” that provides that, when “substantive predicates are 
19 
Memorandum in Support of Motion for Summary Judgment 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 263-1   Filed 10/02/20   Page 28 of 69   Page ID
#:5766
 
1 present,  a  particular  outcome  must  follow.”    8  U.S.C.  § 1232(c)(2)(A).    The 
2 TVPRA’s use of the word “shall” does not mandate a particular outcome.  See 
3 Connecticut  Bd.  of  Pardons  v.  Dumschat,  452  U.S.  458,  466  (1981).    The 
4 “‘expectation of receiving process is not, without more, a liberty interest protected 
5 by the Due Process Clause’ of the Fourteenth Amendment.”  Carver v. Lehman, 558 
6 F.3d 869, 875 (9th Cir. 2009) (quoting Olim v. Wakinekona, 461 U.S. 238, 250-51 
7 n. 12 (1983)).  Here, the TVPRA uses broad language that directs the Secretary to 
8 consider “danger” to self or others in making placement decisions and delegates to 
9 the Secretary equally broad authority to “prescribe” the “procedures” used to review 
10 secure placements and determine if the “placement remains warranted.”  8 U.S.C. 
11 § 1232(c)(2)(A).  The statute does not mandate a particular outcome or require ORR 
12 to adopt a particular set of procedures.  See Hayward v. Marshall, 603 F.3d 546, 560 
13 (9th Cir. 2010) (holding that because parole is a discretionary, predictive decision, 
14 it does not create a protected liberty interest) (en banc).  Thus, the TVPRA does not 
15 create a protected liberty interest in placement in a non-restrictive setting. 
16 Plaintiffs’ claimed liberty interest under the Flores Settlement similarly fails.   
17 Even if a consent decree could confer a protected liberty interest in limited instances, 
18 it does not do so here.  To begin, although the Ninth Circuit has suggested that 
19 Thompson’s two-part test for ascertaining protected liberty interests can, under some 
20 circumstances, be applied to consent decrees, see Smith v. Sumner, 994 F.2d 1401, 
21 1405-06 (9th Cir. 1993), the Ninth Circuit has never held that a consent decree can 
22 expand  on  itself,  creating  protected  liberty  interests  that  mandate  additional 
23 procedures the parties never negotiated or agreed upon.  To hold otherwise would 
24 be to contravene the rule that a “consent decree, like a contract, must be discerned 
25 within its four corners.”  United States v. Asarco Inc., 430 F.3d 972, 980 (9th Cir. 
26 2005).  It would also conflict with this Court’s ruling in Flores that procedural 
27 remedies (like the ones sought here) are not available to Plaintiffs for violations of 
28 the Settlement.  See Flores v. Barr, Case No. 2:85-cv-04544, ECF No. 470 at 2-3 
20

2 injunctive relief, and the court in that case ruled that the consent decree at issue did 
3 not create the claimed liberty interest.  Smith, 994 F.2d at 1407 (holding “the right 
4 to retain counsel conferred by the consent decree is not itself a protected liberty 
5 interest.”).

8 contain  “explicitly  mandatory  language”  that  when  “substantive  predicates  are 
9 present, a particular outcome must follow.”  Thompson, 490 U.S. at 463.  Paragraph 
10 19 of the Settlement provides that UACs “shall be placed temporarily in a licensed 
11 program until such time as release can be effected in accordance with Paragraph 14” 
12 except  in  circumstances  articulated under Paragraph 21.  Paragraph  21 in turn 
13 delegates broad authority to the government to place a UAC in a secure facility, 
14 including when the minor “has committed, or has made credible threats to commit, 
15 a violent or malicious act” or “has engaged, while in a licensed program, in conduct 
16 that has proven to be unacceptably disruptive of the normal functioning of the 
17 licensed program” (¶¶ 24B, 24C), and again does not mandate a particular outcome 
18 or set of procedures.  See Hayward, 603 F.3d at 560.  Thus, like the TVPRA, the 
19 Flores Settlement also does not create a protected liberty interest in placement in a 
20 non-restrictive setting.  
21 Second,  Plaintiffs’  asserted  due-process  interest  in  freedom  from 
22 “unnecessary  physical  restraint”  has  limited  force  as  applied  to  ORR  step-up 
23 decisions.  The Supreme Court has recognized that children, “unlike adults, are 
24 always in some form of custody.”  Reno v. Flores, 507 U.S. at 302; Schall v. Martin, 
25 467 U.S. 253, 265 (1984).  Thus, every child’s interest in freedom from custody is 
26 constrained, whether that child is in ORR custody by statutory mandate or in the 
27 custody of a private guardian.

1 Further, even if UACs in ORR care have a general liberty interest in freedom

6 naturalization,  ‘Congress  regularly  makes  rules  that  would  be  unacceptable  if

8 confined with no ability to secure his or her release.  See, e.g., In re Gault, 387 U.S. 
9 1 (1967).  The minor thus has no control over the length (or terms) of his or her 
10 detention, and additional, procedural safeguards are warranted to ensure that the 
11 greater loss of liberty comports with due process.  Minors in the ORR context, by

15 of the UAC—none of these options are available in the juvenile detention context.  
16 8 U.S.C. §§ 1229c, 1232(a)(5)(D); 8 C.F.R. § 240.25; cf. Parra v. Perryman, 172

18 of the removal proceeding and return home to his native land, thus ending his

13 at  303.    As  explained,  when  ORR  places  a  child  in  a  secure,  staff-secure,  or

7 explains why the minor has been placed in a more restrictive setting, the minor’s

9 Director.  U.F. ¶¶ 54, 56, 64; J.S. ¶ 76.  The Notice is provided in English and

11 language.  U.F. ¶¶ 54, 57.

15 Although the immigration judge’s decision in bond hearings does not bind ORR, 
16 ORR considers the decision in setting the level of placement.  U.F. ¶ 66.  “The [bond] 
17 hearing is a forum in which a child has the right to be represented by counsel, and to 
18 have the merits of his or her detention assessed by an independent immigration 
19 judge.”  Flores, 862 F.3d at 867.  Paragraph 24B of the Flores Settlement also 
20 provides UACs the ability to seek judicial review of placement decisions, which are 
21 reviewed for abuse of discretion (¶ 24C).  U.F. ¶ 63.  Flores bond hearings and 
22 judicial proceedings are both hearings before a neutral decisionmaker, and both can 
23 take place within 30 days of placement at the UAC’s request.

25 facility with an internal administrative appeal process 30 days after placement, 
26 through which the UAC can either request a hearing or submit a written statement.

28 members with extensive child-welfare and mental-health backgrounds, and ORR

9 the ORR Director.  U.F. ¶¶ 64, 67.  Such placements are also reviewed at least every 
10 30 days by the federal field specialist, case coordinator, and case manager, and are 
11 separately reviewed by an ORR monitoring group within the same timeframe.  U.F. 
12 ¶¶ 58, 60.  Third, ORR’s interest in being able to make prompt placement decisions 
13 without  unnecessary  delay  is  substantial  and  outweighs  the  probable  value  of 
14 imposing  additional  procedures  that  will  delay  needed  care  and  treatment  and 
15 consume government resources without significantly reducing the likelihood of an 
16 erroneous deprivation.  ORR’s procedures for stepping up children in its care to more 
17 restrictive settings thus fully comport with due process, and Defendants are entitled 
18 to judgment as a matter of law on Plaintiffs’ step-up claim.

a.  Private interests 
9
10 Plaintiffs  allege  that  children  in  ORR  care  have  three  protected  liberty 
11 interests that are affected by ORR’s release decisions: (1) a statutory interest under 
12 the TVPRA and related contractual interest under the Flores Settlement to be placed

16 outweighed by the other Mathews factors. 
17 To start, Plaintiffs claim a liberty interest in release because the TVPRA 
18 provides that UACs must be placed “in the least restrictive setting that is in the best 
19 interest of the child,” 8 U.S.C. § 1232(c)(2)(A).  See Compl. ¶ 104 (alleging that the 
20 TVPRA “requires ORR to ‘promptly’ place detained children ‘in the least restrictive 
21 setting that is in the best interest of the child,’ generally, with ‘a suitable family 
22 member”).  But that provision of the TVPRA concerns the level of restrictiveness of 
23 the facility in which a minor is placed, and not when they are released.  Immediately 
24 after  the  language  quoted  by  Plaintiffs,  the  statute  reads:  “In  making  such 
25 placements, the Secretary may consider danger to self, danger to the community, and 
26 risk of flight.”  8 U.S.C. § 1232(c)(2)(A) (emphasis added).  Although the provision 
27 later refers to the availability of a “suitable family member,” it does so in the context 
28 of placement decisions—not release—for a particular subcategory of UACs (child

1 trafficking victims), and even then does not require placement with family members.  
2 See  id.  (“Placement  of  child  trafficking  victims  may  include  placement  in  an 
3 Unaccompanied  Refugee  Minor  program,  pursuant  to  section  412(d)  of  the 
4 Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. § 1522(d)), if a suitable family member 
5 is not available to provide care.”).  Thus, the TVPRA does not impose an affirmative 
6 obligation on ORR to expeditiously release UACs to potential sponsors, nor does it 
7 create procedural rights for UACs to contest the denial of release.   
8 Indeed, the TVPRA provision applicable to release decisions provides broad 
9 discretion to the Secretary.  It provides that “an unaccompanied alien child may not 
10 be placed with a person or entity unless the Secretary of Health and Human Services 
11 makes a determination that the proposed custodian is capable of providing for the 
12 child’s  physical  and  mental  well-being.”    8  U.S.C.  § 1232(c)(3)(A)  (emphasis 
13 added).    And  the  TVPRA  sets  only  a  minimum  standard  for  release:  “Such 
14 determination shall, at a minimum, include verification of the custodian’s identity 
15 and relationship to the child, if any, as well as an independent finding that the 
16 individual has not engaged in any activity that would indicate a potential risk to the 
17 child.”  Id.  The TVPRA thus contains no “explicitly mandatory language” imposing 
18 a maximum timeframe for when release decisions must be made, nor does it provide 
19 “specific directives to the decisionmaker” that if release does not occur within a set 
20 timeframe, “a particular outcome must follow.”  Thompson, 490 U.S. at 462-63.  
21 Rather,  the  TVPRA  entrusts  release  determinations  to  ORR’s  discretion  and 
22 expertise to ensure the safety and well-being of UACs in ORR custody and care.  See 
23 Hayward, 603 F.3d at 560 (holding that because parole is a discretionary, predictive 
24 decision, it does not create a protected liberty interest).  Thus, Plaintiffs’ claimed 
25 liberty interest in release under the TVPRA fails.

11 Second, ORR’s policies and procedures for the unfit-custodian class also 
12 comport with the APA.  Compl. ¶ 181.  Plaintiffs similarly make no independent 
13 claim under the APA beyond their procedural-due-process claim, which fails for the 
14 reasons described above, and the relief they request under the APA is the same as 
15 the relief they request on their due-process claim—an opportunity to contest the 
16 denial of release to any potential sponsor.  Further, like the TVPRA, the APA does 
17 not separately impose additional procedural requirements on ORR release decisions.  
18 The unfit-custodian class’s APA claim fails as a matter of law. 
19 Third, to the extent that the unfit-custodian class asserts a claim under the 
20 Freedom of Association Clause of the First Amendment, that claim fails.  See Compl. 
21 ¶ 106.  The First Amendment protects a person’s right to associate with others so as 
22 to protect the person’s right to engage in group activities like speech, that are 
23 themselves protected under the First Amendment.  Dawson v. Delaware, 503 U.S. 
24 159, 163 (1992); see also IDK, Inc. v. Clark Cty., 836 F.2d 1185, 1193 (9th Cir. 
25 1988).  The First Amendment right of association also protects the right to band 
26 together to pursue a common goal.  See Boy Scouts of America v. Dale, 530 U.S. 
27 640, 647-48 (2000).  Nothing in the complaint alleges that class members have been 
28 prevented by ORR from associating with others to exercise other First Amendment

12 On the first Mathews factor, Plaintiffs lack a constitutionally protected interest

25 and protect them from mistreatment.”  8 U.S.C. § 1232(c)(5).  The statute pertains 
26 to pro bono legal services: “To the greatest extent practicable, the Secretary of 
27 Health and Human Services shall make every effort to utilize the services of pro

12 the claim. 
13 3) ORR’s  policies  and  procedures  for  the  legal-representation  class 
comport with the TVPRA, the HSA, Title 8, and the APA.   
14
15 ORR’s policies and procedures for the legal-representation class satisfy the 
16 requirements of the TVPRA, the HSA, Title 8, and the APA as a matter of law.  
17 Plaintiffs allege that these statutes and associated regulations “generally guarantee 
18 Plaintiffs and their proposed class members the right to be represented by retained 
19 and pro bono counsel in proceedings before U.S. Citizenship  and  Immigration 
20 Services  and  the  Executive  Office  for  Immigration  Review.”    Compl.  ¶ 144.  
21 Plaintiffs further allege that “[l]egal proceedings involving ORR’s custody, release, 
22 placement, and medication decisions, including hearings pursuant to paragraph 24A 
23 of the Flores Settlement, are ‘legal proceedings or matters’ within the meaning of 
24 the TVPRA § 235(c)(5).”  Id. ¶ 149.  These arguments lack merit: such a right is not 
25 articulated in any of the statutes or regulations that Plaintiffs cite.  The Court should 
26 therefore  reject  the  claim  that  ORR’s  policies  and  procedures  “violate  . . .  the 
27 TVPRA  § 235(c)(5),  HSA  § 279(b)(A)  [sic],  8  C.F.R.  §§ 287.3(c),  1003.62, 
28 1240.10(a)(2) and 1292.1 et seq. [collectively, the federal immigration regulations 
57 
Memorandum in Support of Motion for Summary Judgment 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 263-1   Filed 10/02/20   Page 66 of 69   Page ID
#:5804
 
1 under Title 8],” and the APA, as applied to the legal-representation class.  Compl. 
2 ¶ 190.   
3 First,  Plaintiffs’  claim  under  the  TVPRA  fails,  as  the  TVPRA  nowhere 
4 specifies a right to access government-funded counsel to challenge routine ORR 
5 decision-making.  The TVPRA instructs ORR to “ensure, to the greatest extent 
6 practicable and consistent with section 292 of the Immigration and Nationality Act 
7 (8 U.S.C. § 1362), that all unaccompanied alien children who are or have been in the 
8 custody of [HHS] . . . have counsel to represent them in legal proceedings or matters 
9 and protect them from mistreatment.”  8 U.S.C. § 1232(c)(5).  Section 292 of the 
10 INA in turn provides that “[i]n any removal proceedings before an immigration 
11 judge and in any appeal proceedings before the Attorney General from any such 
12 removal  proceedings,  the  person  concerned  shall  have  the  privilege  of  being 
13 represented (at no expense to the Government) by such counsel, authorized to 
14 practice in such proceedings, as he shall choose.”  8 U.S.C. § 1362 (emphasis added).  
15 These provisions do not create a general right to access government-funded counsel 
16 to  challenge  routine  ORR  decisions,  such  as  step-up,  release,  and  medication.  
17 Rather, these provisions impose an obligation on ORR to connect UACs with pro 
18 bono counsel in their immigration proceedings.  And as explained, ORR’s policies 
19 and procedures on legal representation satisfy this obligation, as ORR works to 
20 ensure  “to  the  greatest  extent  practicable”  that  UACs  are  able  to  access  such 
21 representation.  U.F. ¶ 81.  Thus, Plaintiffs’ claim that ORR’s policies and practices 
22 on legal representation violate the TVPRA fails as a matter of law. 
23 To the extent that Plaintiffs claim that challenges to routine ORR decision-
24 making on release, step-up, and the administration of psychotropic medication are 
25 “legal proceedings” covered under subsection (c)(5) of the TVPRA, such a claim 
26 conflicts with a plain reading of the statute, its legislative history, and congressional 
27 appropriations.  To start, the TVPRA plainly states that it must be applied “consistent 
28 with” section 292 of the INA (8 U.S.C. § 1362), and that provision addresses access 
58 
Memorandum in Support of Motion for Summary Judgment 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 263-1   Filed 10/02/20   Page 67 of 69   Page ID
#:5805
 
1 to counsel in “removal proceedings.”  Further, such a reading  contravenes the 
2 TVPRA’s legislative history.  One of the main sponsors of the TVPRA, Senator 
3 Diane  Feinstein,  introduced  the  finalized  bill  as  follows:  “This  trafficking  bill 
4 includes a provision I authored over 8 years ago—the Unaccompanied Alien Minor 
5 Act . . . .  The bill also provides for pro bono legal representation for unaccompanied 
6 alien children in their immigration matters . . . .”  154 Cong. Rec. S10, 886-87 (daily 
7 ed.  Dec.  10,  2008).    Finally,  congressional  appropriations  show  that  Congress 
8 intended to fund only access to immigration services.  For the current fiscal year 
9 2020, Congress set aside not less than $160 million for three areas: legal services, 
10 child advocates, and post-release services.  See Further Consolidated Appropriations 
11 Act, 2020, Pub. L. 116-94, Division A, Title II, 133 Stat. 2570.  Statements of the 
12 House  Appropriations  Committee  Chairwoman,  Chairwoman  DeLauro,  further 
13 show that this funding is designated for assisting children in obtaining representation 
14 in immigration proceedings: “[L]egal counsel for unaccompanied children increases 
15 the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  immigration  proceedings  and  significantly 
16 reduces the failure-to-appear rate of children who are released from HHS custody.”  
17 H.R. Rep. 116-62, 144-45, 116th Congress, 1st Sess. (May 15, 2019).  
18 Read in context, the TVPRA addresses legal representation in immigration 
19 removal proceedings, not the day-to-day decisions that Plaintiffs characterize as 
20 “legal proceedings.”  And ORR has never considered challenges to step-up, release, 
21 and medical care to be legal matters or proceedings under the TVPRA.  J.S. ¶ 99.  
22 On  Plaintiffs’  view,  any  day-to-day  custodial  decision  could  become  a  “legal 
23 proceeding,”  including  educational  services,  recreational  activities,  and  routine 
24 medical care.  Plaintiffs provide no basis for this sweeping view of the statute, which 
25 was intended to “provide[ ] for pro bono legal representation for unaccompanied 
26 alien children in their immigration matters.”  154 Cong. Rec. S10, 886-87. 
27 Second, Plaintiffs’ claim under the HSA fails.  Like the TVPRA, the HSA 
28 does not create a right to access government-funded counsel to challenge ORR 
59 
Memorandum in Support of Motion for Summary Judgment 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 263-1   Filed 10/02/20   Page 68 of 69   Page ID
#:5806
 
1 decisions on step-up, release, and medication.  Section 279(b)(1)(A) of the HSA 
2 directs ORR to “develop[ ] a plan to be submitted to Congress on how to ensure that 
3 qualified and independent legal counsel is timely appointed to represent the interests 
4 of each such [unaccompanied alien] child,” but does not require ORR to provide 
5 access to government-funded legal representation in these matters.   
6 Third, Plaintiffs’ claim fails under federal immigration regulations, including 
7 8 C.F.R. §§ 287.3(c), 1003.62, 1240.10(a)(2), and 1292.1 et seq.  Those regulations 
8 generally provide arriving aliens with the opportunity to retain their own counsel in 
9 proceedings before U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services and the Executive 
10 Office for Immigration Review, but make no mention of legal representation in ORR 
11 custody to contest other  decisions unrelated  to immigration relief,  nor do  they 
12 require access to government-funded counsel.   
13 Finally,  ORR’s  policies  and  procedures  for  the legal-representation  class 
14 comport with the APA.  Plaintiffs make no independent claim under the APA beyond 
15 their procedural-due-process claim, which fails for the reasons described, and the 
16 relief they seek under the APA is the same relief they seek on their due-process 
17 claim—access to government-funded legal counsel to challenge ORR decisions on 
18 step-up, release, and medication.  In addition, like the TVPRA, HSA, and federal 
19 immigration regulation provisions discussed above, the APA does not separately 
20 impose a right to access government-funded counsel.   
21 The legal-representation class’s claims under all these statutes fail as a matter 
22 of law.  
23
VI.  Conclusion 
24
The Court should grant summary judgment for Defendants on the step-up, 
25
unfit-custodian, and legal-representation class’s claims.   
26
27
28

documents.title: Proceedings: In Chambers - Order Re Plaintiff Lucas R.'s Motion for Preliminary Injunction [29]
documents.text:
Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 79   Filed 09/06/18   Page 1 of 9   Page ID #:3042
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL 
 
Case No.  CV 18-5741-DMG (PLAx)  Date  September 6, 2018 
   
Title  Lucas R., et al. v. Alex Azar, et al.  Page  1 of 9 
   
 
Present: The Honorable  DOLLY M. GEE, UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE 
   
KANE TIEN    NOT REPORTED 
Deputy Clerk    Court Reporter 
     
Attorneys Present for Plaintiff(s)    Attorneys Present for Defendant(s) 
None Present    None Present 
 
Proceedings:  IN CHAMBERS - ORDER RE PLAINTIFF LUCAS R.’S MOTION FOR 
PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION [29] 
 
  On June 29, 2018, Plaintiffs Lucas R., Daniela Marisol T., Miguel Angel S., Gabriela N., 
Jaime D., San Fernando Valley Refugee Children Center, Inc., and Unaccompanied Central 
American Refugee Empowerment filed a Class Action Complaint for Declaratory, Injunctive, and 
Nominal Monetary Relief (“CAC”) against Alex Azar, the Secretary of the U.S. Department of 
Health and Human Services (“HHS”), and E. Scott Lloyd, the Director of the Office of Refugee 
Resettlement (“ORR”).  [Doc. # 1.]  The CAC alleges that ORR maintains certain policies and/or 
practices relating to the detention of alien minors that violate (inter alia) the Due Process Clause 
of the Fifth Amendment, the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization 
Act (“TVPRA”), and the consent decree issued in Flores v. Sessions, No. CV 85-4544-DMG 
(AGRx) (C.D. Cal.) [Doc. # 101] (“Flores Agreement”).  CAC at 1–5, 39–41.1 
 
  On August 3, 2018, Plaintiff Lucas R. filed a motion for preliminary injunction, wherein 
he seeks an order requiring ORR to immediately release him to Madelyn R., his next friend and 
sister.  [Doc. # 29.]  The motion for preliminary injunctive relief has since been fully briefed.  
[Doc. ## 44, 53.]  Having duly considered the parties’ written submissions, the Court DENIES, 
without prejudice, Lucas R.’s motion for the reasons set forth below. 
 
I. 
FACTUAL BACKGROUND 
 
  Lucas  R.  is  a  native  and  citizen  of  Guatemala  who  entered  the  United  States  in 
February 2018.  See CAC at ¶ 10; Opp’n re Lucas R.’s MPI at 2; Pls.’ Class Cert. Mot., Ex. 21 at 
¶ 2 (Lucas R. Decl.) [Doc. # 35-12]; CAC at ¶ 21; Opp’n re Lucas R.’s MPI at 2; Opp’n re Lucas 
R.’s MPI, Ex. 45 at ¶ 7 (De La Cruz Decl.) [Doc. # 44-1].  On or about February 12, 2018, ORR 
assumed custody of Lucas and placed him in the Southwest Key Hacienda del Sol shelter in 
                                                 
1 All page references herein are to page numbers inserted by the CM/ECF system. 
 
CV-90  CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL  Initials of Deputy Clerk KT 
 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 79   Filed 09/06/18   Page 2 of 9   Page ID #:3043
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL 
 
Case No.  CV 18-5741-DMG (PLAx)  Date  September 6, 2018 
   
Title  Lucas R., et al. v. Alex Azar, et al.  Page  2 of 9 
   
 
Youngtown, Arizona.2  See Lucas R’s. MPI, Ex. 33 at 2 (Admission Record) [Doc. # 39-1]; Opp’n 
re Lucas R.’s MPI, Ex. 45 at ¶ 8 (De La Cruz Decl.) [Doc. # 44-1].  On May 21, 2018, ORR 
transferred Lucas to Shiloh Residential Treatment Center (“Shiloh RTC”) in Manvel, Texas.  
Lucas R.’s MPI, Ex. 42 at 2–3 (ORR Transfer Request and Tracking Form) [Doc. # 39-9].  To this 
day, ORR continues to detain Lucas at Shiloh RTC.  See Lucas R.’s MPI at 9; Opp’n re Lucas R.’s 
MPI at 10–11; Opp’n re Lucas R.’s MPI, Ex. 45 at ¶¶ 13, 20, 22 (De La Cruz Decl.) [Doc. # 44-
1].   
 
    In mid-February 2018, Madelyn R. asked ORR to release Lucas to her custody.  See Pls.’ 
Class Cert. Mot., Ex. 22 at ¶ 6 (Madelyn R. Decl.) [Doc. # 35-13].  In March 2018, ORR conducted 
a home study to determine whether Madelyn was a suitable custodian for Lucas.  See id. at ¶ 10.  
The social worker visited Madelyn’s home on several more occasions over the next two weeks.  
See id. at ¶¶ 11–12.  Approximately one month after the social worker’s final visit, she informed 
Madelyn that ORR denied her request because an individual suspected of being a resident of the 
home had refused to be fingerprinted.  See id. at ¶ 13.  Although the social worker stated that this 
decision was final, she failed to provide Madelyn with a written decision or explain whether 
Madelyn could appeal ORR’s denial of her request.  See id. 
 
Lucas claims that he is entitled to release from custody under Paragraphs 14 and 18 of the 
Flores Agreement, which require ORR to release a minor from its custody without unnecessary 
delay, see Flores Agreement at ¶¶ 14, 18, and under Section 235(c)(2)(A) of the TVPRA, which 
obligates ORR to promptly place an unaccompanied alien child in the least restrictive setting that 
is in the best interest of the child, see 8 U.S.C. § 1232(c)(2)(A).  Lucas further contends that ORR 
has deprived him of his constitutional rights to physical liberty, family unity, and familial 
association without due process of law by failing to provide Lucas or Madelyn with “any 
meaningful process by which they may contest ORR’s [decision that] Madelyn [is] an unfit 
custodian.”  See Lucas R.’s MPI at 23–26.  Lucas argues that these constitutional violations warrant 
his immediate release to Madelyn because ORR “cannot be reasonably expected to fashion” an 
adequate hearing procedure “without protracting Lucas’s detention even more and causing him 
even greater irreparable injury.”  See Reply re Lucas R.’s MPI at 13–14. 
 
 
 
 
                                                 
2 The TVPRA provides that HHS is responsible for the custody of all unaccompanied alien children.  See 8 
U.S.C. § 1232(b)(1).  ORR is the division of HHS that has been entrusted with that responsibility.  See Saravia v. 
Sessions, 280 F. Supp. 3d 1168, 1178 (N.D. Cal. 2017).  There is no dispute that Lucas is an unaccompanied alien 
child.  See Compl. at ¶ 10; Opp’n re Lucas R.’s MPI at 2.  
CV-90  CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL  Initials of Deputy Clerk KT 
 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 79   Filed 09/06/18   Page 3 of 9   Page ID #:3044
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL 
 
Case No.  CV 18-5741-DMG (PLAx)  Date  September 6, 2018 
   
Title  Lucas R., et al. v. Alex Azar, et al.  Page  3 of 9 
   
 
II. 
LEGAL STANDARD 
 
  A plaintiff seeking preliminary injunctive relief must show that:  (1) he or she is likely to 
succeed on the merits; (2) he or she is likely to suffer irreparable harm in the absence of preliminary 
relief; (3) the balance of equities tips in his or her favor; and (4) an injunction is in the public 
interest.  Toyo Tire Holdings of Ams. Inc. v. Cont’l Tire N. Am., Inc., 609 F.3d 975, 982 (9th Cir. 
2010) (citing Winter v. Nat. Res. Def. Council, Inc., 555 U.S. 7, 20 (2008)).  An injunction is also 
appropriate when a plaintiff raises “serious questions going to the merits,” demonstrates that “the 
balance of hardships tips sharply in [his or her] favor,” and “shows that there is a likelihood of 
irreparable injury and that the injunction is in the public interest.”  All. for the Wild Rockies v. 
Cottrell, 632 F.3d 1127, 1135 (9th Cir. 2011) (quoting Lands Council v. McNair, 537 F.3d 981, 
987 (9th Cir. 2008)).  “A federal court may issue an injunction if it has personal jurisdiction over 
the parties and subject matter jurisdiction over the claim; it may not attempt to determine the rights 
of persons not before the court.”  Zepeda v. INS, 753 F.2d 719, 727 (9th Cir. 1983).  
 
III. 
DISCUSSION 
 
  Lucas R. identifies three jurisdictional bases for his request for preliminary injunctive 
relief:  (1) the Flores Agreement, (2) 28 U.S.C. section 2241 (i.e., the habeas statute for federal 
prisoners), and (3) the Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”).3  See Reply re Lucas R.’s MPI at 
9–17.  None of these authorities, however, permits this Court to grant Lucas the relief he seeks—
i.e., his release from ORR’s custody.  See Notice of Lucas R.’s MPI at 3 [Doc. # 29]; Lucas R.’s 
MPI at 6 (“Plaintiffs seek a preliminary injunction requiring [Lucas’s] immediate release.”). 
 
                                                 
3 Lucas R. also argues that the TVPRA and 28 U.S.C. section 1331 “vest[] th[is] Court with full authority to 
compel ORR to place [him] in the least restrictive setting consistent with his best interests and to do so without further 
delay.”  See Reply re Lucas R.’s MPI at 15.  Admittedly, the TVPRA does provide that “an unaccompanied alien child 
in the custody of [ORR] shall be promptly placed in the least restrictive setting that is in the best interest of the child.”  
See 8 U.S.C. § 1232(c)(2)(A).  Nonetheless, Lucas. R. does not identify any provision of the TVPRA that confers 
jurisdiction on this Court to release him from custody, nor is it apparent that any such provision exists.  Further, 28 
U.S.C. section 1331 does not authorize this Court to compel Lucas R.’s release.  Rather, it simply confers jurisdiction 
over causes of action created by federal law and certain state law claims that are predicated on federal law.  See 
Williston Basin Interstate Pipeline Co. v. An Exclusive Gas Storage Leasehold & Easement in the Cloverly 
Subterranean Geological Formation, 524 F.3d 1090, 1100 (9th Cir. 2008).  Moreover, Section 1331, standing alone, 
does not waive ORR’s sovereign immunity.  See Holloman v. Watt, 708 F.2d 1399, 1401 (9th Cir. 1983) (“Section 
1331 does not waive the government’s sovereign immunity from suit.”); FDIC v. Meyer, 510 U.S. 471, 475 (1994) 
(“Absent a waiver, sovereign immunity shields the Federal Government and its agencies from suit.”).      
CV-90  CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL  Initials of Deputy Clerk KT 
 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 79   Filed 09/06/18   Page 4 of 9   Page ID #:3045
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL 
 
Case No.  CV 18-5741-DMG (PLAx)  Date  September 6, 2018 
   
Title  Lucas R., et al. v. Alex Azar, et al.  Page  4 of 9 
   
 
A.  The Flores Agreement Does Not Authorize This Court to Release Lucas R. 
 
Lucas  R.  asserts  that  this  Court  has  jurisdiction  to  hear  his  motion  for  preliminary 
injunction pursuant to Paragraph 37 of the Flores Agreement.  See Reply re Lucas R.’s MPI at 9–
12.  Paragraph 37 provides in pertinent part:  “This paragraph provides for the enforcement, in this 
District Court, of the provisions of this Agreement except for claims brought under Paragraph 24.”  
Flores Agreement at ¶ 37. 
 
In turn, Paragraph 24B of the Agreement provides: 
 
Any minor who disagrees with the INS’s determination to place that minor in a 
particular type of facility, or who asserts that the licensed program in which he or 
she has been placed does not comply with the standards set forth in Exhibit 1 
attached hereto, may seek judicial review in any United States District Court with 
jurisdiction and venue over the matter to challenge that placement determination or 
to allege noncompliance with the standards set forth in Exhibit 1.  In such an action, 
the United States District Court shall be limited to entering an order solely affecting 
the individual claims of the minor bringing the action. 
 
Id. at ¶ 24B. 
 
  Lucas R. argues that Paragraph 24B is inapplicable because it governs only challenges to 
a minor’s placement in a particular ORR facility.  See Reply re Lucas R.’s MPI at 9 & n.2.  An 
objection to ORR’s refusal to release a particular Flores Class Member from its custody, however, 
also constitutes a challenge to the agency’s decision to place the Class Member in an ORR facility 
rather than release the minor to a proposed custodian.  This conclusion is reinforced by certain 
provisions of the Flores Agreement that indicate that release and placement decisions are not 
mutually exclusive.  See, e.g., Flores Agreement at ¶ 11 (providing that the purpose of the 
Agreement is to ensure that ORR “place[s] each detained minor in the least restrictive setting 
appropriate to the minor’s age and special needs,” which suggests that declining to release a minor 
is a “placement” decision); see also Powerine Oil Co. v. Superior Court of L.A. Cty., 37 Cal. 4th 
377, 391 (2003) (“[L]anguage in a contract must be construed in the context of that instrument as 
a whole . . . .” (quoting Bank of the West v. Superior Court of Contra Costa Cty., 2 Cal. 4th 1254, 
1265 (1992)) (internal quotation marks omitted));4 8 U.S.C. § 1232(c)(2)(A) (providing that ORR 
shall review “[t]he placement of a child in a secure facility” on a monthly basis, implying that 
continuing to detain a minor is a “placement” decision).  In fact, in an attempt to show that a 
                                                 
4 California contract law governs the interpretation of the Flores Agreement.  See O’Neil v. Bunge Corp., 
365 F.3d 820, 822 (9th Cir. 2004). 
CV-90  CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL  Initials of Deputy Clerk KT 
 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 79   Filed 09/06/18   Page 5 of 9   Page ID #:3046
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL 
 
Case No.  CV 18-5741-DMG (PLAx)  Date  September 6, 2018 
   
Title  Lucas R., et al. v. Alex Azar, et al.  Page  5 of 9 
   
 
petition for writ of habeas corpus is not the only means by which he can obtain the relief sought, 
Lucas concedes that he challenges ORR’s decision not to place him in the least restrictive setting—
i.e., in the custody of Madelyn R.  See Reply re Lucas R.’s MPI at 12 (“[Lucas R.’s] claim that 
ORR’s refusing to place him with Madelyn violates the TVPRA is not about ‘release’ at all.  
Rather, it is about placement in the least restrictive setting consistent with his best interests.” 
(emphasis added)); see also Proposed Order re Lucas R.’s MPI at 3 (“IT IS ORDERED that 
Defendants shall place Lucas with his sister, Madelyn R., by no later than September 3, 2018.” 
(emphasis added)) [Doc. # 53-4].  It follows that no matter how Lucas chooses to frame the relief 
he seeks, it falls within the scope of Paragraph 24B and is excluded from Paragraph 37’s general 
grant of jurisdiction to this Court. 
 
  In arriving at this conclusion, the Court does not suggest that all disputes relating to the 
release of Flores Class Members must be brought in the “United States District Court with 
jurisdiction and venue over the matter[.]”  Flores Agreement at ¶ 24B.  The text of Paragraphs 24B 
and 37 establishes that:  (1) such courts have the exclusive authority to hear a particular minor’s 
assertion that he or she should be released from ORR custody or afforded the benefits of a licensed 
program, and (2) this Court is empowered to remedy systemic violations of the Agreement that 
affect multiple Class Members (e.g., a class-wide challenge to an ORR policy affecting the release 
rights of all minors in the agency’s custody based on the nationwide standards of the Flores 
Agreement).  Specifically, Paragraph 24B discusses “that minor[’s]” (i.e., the minor bringing a 
claim covered by that provision) placement and Exhibit 1 challenges, and provides that the district 
court hearing those claims “shall be limited to entering an order solely affecting the individual 
claims of the minor bringing the action.”  See id. (emphasis added); see also MacKinnon v. Truck 
Ins. Exch., 31 Cal. 4th 635, 653 (2003) (holding that the “plain meaning” of a contract term is 
controlling); Flores v. Lynch, 828 F.3d 898, 903 (9th Cir. 2016) (“The [Flores Agreement] 
generally provides for the enforcement in the Central District of California, but allows individual 
challenges to placement or detention conditions to be brought in any district court with jurisdiction 
and venue.”  (emphasis added) (citations omitted) (citing Flores Agreement at ¶¶ 24B, 37)). 
 
The  apparent  purpose  of  Paragraph  24B  further  supports  this  interpretation.    See 
MacKinnon,  31  Cal.  4th  at  653  (holding  that  the  “purpose”  of  a  clause  is  relevant  to  its 
interpretation, although it is not determinative).  If a minor asserts that he or she should be released 
(e.g., because a particular custodian is suitable) or that he or she has been denied the protections 
of Exhibit 1 to the Agreement (e.g., the class member was administered psychotropic medication 
in violation of state child welfare laws), then a court must undertake an individualized (as opposed 
to class-wide) analysis of such claims.  In such cases, the convenience of the parties and witnesses 
CV-90  CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL  Initials of Deputy Clerk KT 
 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 79   Filed 09/06/18   Page 6 of 9   Page ID #:3047
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL 
 
Case No.  CV 18-5741-DMG (PLAx)  Date  September 6, 2018 
   
Title  Lucas R., et al. v. Alex Azar, et al.  Page  6 of 9 
   
 
would most often weigh in favor of requiring the minor to bring the action in one particular 
forum—i.e., the district court that otherwise has jurisdiction and venue.5 
 
In sum, the Court lacks jurisdiction over Lucas R.’s claim that he is entitled to release under 
the Flores Agreement because it does not fall within the scope of Paragraph 37.  Rather, his claim 
is governed by Paragraph 24B, and must therefore be brought in the “United States District Court 
with jurisdiction and venue over the matter[.]”  See Flores Agreement at ¶ 24B.  
 
B.  This Court Lacks Jurisdiction to Release Lucas R. Under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 
 
“[I]n habeas challenges to present physical confinement—‘core challenges’—the default 
rule is that the proper respondent is the warden of the facility where the prisoner is being held, not 
the Attorney General or some other remote supervisory official.”6  See Rumsfeld v. Padilla, 542 
U.S. 426, 436 (2004) (emphasis added).  The rationale for this so-called “immediate custodian 
rule” is that the habeas statute “contemplate[s] a proceeding against some person who has the 
immediate custody of the party detained, with the power to produce the body of such party before 
the court or judge that he may be liberated if no sufficient reason is shown to the contrary.”  See 
id. at 435 (quoting Wales v. Whitney, 114 U.S. 564, 574 (1885)) (internal quotation marks omitted).  
In cases in which this rule applies, only the district court with territorial jurisdiction over the 
custodian may entertain a habeas petition.  See id. at 436, 442–47 (holding that the U.S. District 
Court for the District of South Carolina had exclusive jurisdiction over a habeas petition because 
that was the location of the commander of the brig in which Padilla was confined).   
 
Although Rumsfeld did not explicitly decide whether the immediate custodian rule applies 
to habeas petitions filed by detained aliens, see id. at 435–36 & n.8, “[t]here is no compelling 
distinction between criminal custody and immigration custody” that warrants a departure from the 
default rule.  See Saravia v. Sessions, 280 F. Supp. 3d 1168, 1185 (N.D. Cal. 2017); see also 
Drakoulis v. Ashcroft, 356 F. Supp. 2d 367, 369–71 (S.D.N.Y. 2005) (applying the immediate 
custodian rule to a habeas petition filed by an alien, which requested release from the custody of 
Immigration and Customs and Enforcement); Deng v. Garcia, 356 F. Supp. 2d 367, 374–75 
(E.D.N.Y. 2005) (same).  If the immediate custodian rule did not apply to the latter, then any alien 
                                                 
5 If a minor raises such claims in a habeas petition, then the appropriate forum is the district in which the 
immediate custodian is located.  See infra Part III.B; cf. 28 U.S.C. § 2241(c)(1) (“The writ of habeas corpus shall not 
extend to a prisoner unless . . . [h]e is in custody under or by color of the authority of the United States . . . .”). 
 
6 Although Padilla did not define the precise contours of “core challenges,” the Court held that a request for 
release from custody constitutes such a challenge.  See Rumsfeld v. Padilla, 542 U.S. 426, 438 (2004) (“[T]he 
traditional rule [is] that a prisoner seeking release from confinement must sue his ‘jailer.’”). 
CV-90  CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL  Initials of Deputy Clerk KT 
 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 79   Filed 09/06/18   Page 7 of 9   Page ID #:3048
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL 
 
Case No.  CV 18-5741-DMG (PLAx)  Date  September 6, 2018 
   
Title  Lucas R., et al. v. Alex Azar, et al.  Page  7 of 9 
   
 
could name a high-level supervisory official (e.g., the HHS Secretary or the Director of ORR) as 
a  respondent,  “a  result  ‘the  statutory  language,  established  practice,  and  [Supreme  Court] 
precedent’ counsel against.”  See Saravia, 280 F. Supp. 3d at 1187 (alteration in original) (quoting 
Padilla, 542 U.S. at 439–40).  Additionally, if an alien is detained by a state, local, or private entity 
at the behest of the federal government, then the “immediate custodian” is “the federal official 
tasked with ensuring that [the facility] complies with the requirements of its contract . . . .”  See id. 
at 1186.  This is because the alien is in custody “pursuant to the power and authority of the federal 
government[,]” which is authorized to produce the alien before the court.  See id.  Moreover, the 
state, local, or private entity has less incentive to defend the detention of the alien than does the 
federal official charged with overseeing the contract with the facility.  See id.  
 
  The non-binding decisions that Lucas relies upon for the proposition that the immediate 
custodian rule does not apply to immigration cases are either unpersuasive or arise in sharply 
distinguishable contexts.  Bogarin-Flores v. Holder, No. CV 12-0399 JAH(WMc), 2012 WL 
3283287 (S.D. Cal. Aug. 10, 2012), declined to apply the immediate custodian rule because the 
warden of the private detention facility at issue had no legal authority to release the petitioner and 
no binding Ninth Circuit authority explicitly holds that the rule applies in the immigration context.  
See id. at *1–2.  Yet, Padilla rejected the proposition that the proper respondent is an individual 
who exercises “legal control” over the petitioner.  542 U.S. at 439 (“In challenges to present 
physical confinement, we reaffirm that the immediate custodian, not a supervisory official who 
exercises legal control, is the proper respondent.”).   As Saravia points out, the federal official 
responsible for enforcing the contract—and not the warden of a private contract facility—is the 
immediate custodian.  See Saravia, 280 F. Supp. 3d at 1186–87 (concluding that the federal official 
responsible for enforcing the contract “exercises more immediate control over a contract facility 
than the Attorney General or another department head”).  Furthermore, the absence of direct 
controlling authority is not a persuasive reason to depart from Padilla’s “default rule.”  See, e.g., 
Bracamontes-Reyes v. Sessions, No. CV 18-01301-PHX-DLR (JZB), 2018 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 
76756, at *4 (D. Ariz. May 4, 2018) (declining to apply the immediate custodian rule simply 
because of “the absence of any Ninth Circuit authority precluding [the alien] from naming the 
Attorney General, the Secretary of Homeland Security, or the ICE Phoenix Field Office Director 
as Respondents”).    
 
Further, Rivera v. Holder, 307 F.R.D. 539 (W.D. Wash. 2015), does not mandate a 
departure from the default rule because that case did not involve a “core” habeas claim.  There, the 
plaintiff challenged a policy under which all requests for conditional parole were denied, and she 
sought a class-wide order granting aliens new bond hearings in which immigration judges would 
properly consider such requests.  See id. at 543–44, 548 & n.1.  This distinction between core and 
non-core habeas challenges is essential because Padilla explicitly held that “the immediate 
CV-90  CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL  Initials of Deputy Clerk KT 
 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 79   Filed 09/06/18   Page 8 of 9   Page ID #:3049
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL 
 
Case No.  CV 18-5741-DMG (PLAx)  Date  September 6, 2018 
   
Title  Lucas R., et al. v. Alex Azar, et al.  Page  8 of 9 
   
 
physical custodian rule, by its terms, does not apply when a habeas petitioner challenges something 
other than his present physical confinement.”  See Padilla, 542 U.S. at 438; see also Saravia, 280 
F. Supp. 3d at 1180–82, 1190 (concluding that the immediate custodian was the proper respondent 
for a habeas petition seeking release from custody, but that she was not the proper defendant on a 
claim requesting a hearing before an immigration judge). 
 
Accordingly, the Court concludes that the immediate custodian rule applies to Lucas R.’s 
request for on order releasing him from ORR’s custody.  Saravia found that where, as here, ORR 
detained a minor in a facility operated by a contractor, see Lucas R.’s MPI at 15 n.3; Opp’n re 
Lucas R.’s MPI at 10, the immediate custodian was the ORR Federal Field Specialist responsible 
for enforcing the contract with that facility, see Saravia, 280 F. Supp. 3d at 1186.  The ORR 
Federal Field Specialist responsible for managing the agency’s contract with Shiloh RTC is 
Micaela Vergara, who is located in the Southern District of Texas.  See De La Cruz Decl. at ¶ 2 
[Doc. # 73-1]; 28 U.S.C. § 124(b)(2).  Because this official is not located within the territorial 
jurisdiction of this Court and cannot be named as a party herein, Section 2241 does not authorize 
this Court to order Lucas’s release.    
   
C.  This Court Lacks Jurisdiction to Release Lucas R. Under the APA 
   
  The APA permits judicial review of an agency action only if “there is no other adequate 
remedy in a court[,]” see 5 U.S.C. § 704, which means that a federal court lacks jurisdiction over 
an APA claim if another statute would allow a court to review the allegedly unlawful agency 
action, see Coos Cty. Bd. of Cty. Cm’rs v. Kempthorne, 531 F.3d 791, 810 (9th Cir. 2008) (citing 
5 U.S.C. § 704); Brem-Air Disposal v. Cohen, 156 F.3d 1002, 1004–05 (9th Cir. 1998) (“Under 
APA § 10(c), codified at 5 U.S.C. § 704, federal courts lack jurisdiction over APA challenges 
whenever Congress has provided another ‘adequate remedy.’ * * * ‘If a plaintiff can bring suit 
against the responsible federal agencies under [another statute], this action precludes an additional 
suit under the APA.’” (quoting Envtl. Def. Fund v. Tidwell, 837 F. Supp. 1344, 1356 (E.D.N.C. 
1992))).  An adequate alternative to an APA challenge brought in this Court is available to Lucas 
R.—i.e., a petition for writ of habeas corpus filed in the United States District Court for the 
Southern District of Texas.7  See 28 U.S.C. § 2241(c)(3) (providing that the writ is available to 
                                                 
7 To the extent that the APA authorizes Lucas R. to seek release from custody, he may raise such claims in a 
habeas petition.  See 5 U.S.C. § 703 (“The form of proceeding for judicial review is . . . any applicable form of legal 
action, including actions for . . . habeas corpus.”); Cornejo-Barreto, 218 F.3d 1004, 1015 n.12 (9th Cir. 2000) 
(“[H]abeas corpus is an appropriate form of action under the APA.”), overruled in part on another ground by Trinidad 
y Garcia v. Thomas, 683 F.3d 952, 957 (9th Cir. 2012) (en banc).  Any such habeas petition, however, cannot be 
entertained by this Court.  See supra Part III.B.  
 
CV-90  CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL  Initials of Deputy Clerk KT 
 

Case 2:18-cv-05741-DMG-PLA   Document 79   Filed 09/06/18   Page 9 of 9   Page ID #:3050
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
CIVIL MINUTES—GENERAL 
 
Case No.  CV 18-5741-DMG (PLAx)  Date  September 6, 2018 
   
Title  Lucas R., et al. v. Alex Azar, et al.  Page  9 of 9 
   
 
prisoners “in custody in violation of the Constitution or laws or treaties if the United States”); 
Trinidad y Garcia, 683 F.3d at 956 (“The writ of habeas corpus historically provides a remedy to 
non-citizens challenging executive detention.”); see also Reply re Lucas R.’s MPI at 13 n.6 
(conceding that “aliens may challenge detention via habeas corpus provided they are not under a 
final order of removal”).  Therefore, the APA does not authorize Lucas R. to challenge his present 
physical confinement in this judicial district.8    
 
IV. 
CONCLUSION 
 
  For the foregoing reasons, the Court DENIES, without prejudice, Lucas R.’s motion for 
preliminary injunction, due to lack of jurisdiction.  This Order in no way precludes Lucas R. from 
seeking appropriate relief in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas 
against ORR Federal Field Specialist Micaela Vergara. 
 
IT IS SO ORDERED. 
                                                 
8 Lucas R. nonetheless insists that “the principles animating habeas relief as an exclusive remedy have no 
application here.”  See Reply re Lucas R.’s MPI at 13 n.6.  In particular, he asserts that Preiser v. Rodriguez, 411 U.S. 
475 (1973), held only that a state prisoner may not challenge his or her custody via a claim under 42 U.S.C. section 
1983 but must instead file a habeas petition under 28 U.S.C. section 2254.  See Reply re Lucas R.’s MPI at 13 n.6.  
The Court agrees that Preiser has no bearing on Lucas’s motion.  See Preiser, 411 U.S. at 500 (“[W]e hold today that 
when a state prisoner is challenging the very fact or duration of his physical imprisonment, . . . his sole federal remedy 
is a writ of habeas corpus.”).  Nevertheless, as explained above, Lucas cannot obtain the relief he seeks from this 
Court.
